DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Dunlop, Sir Edward, AC, CMG, OBE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House expresses its deep regret at the death on Friday, 2 July 1993, of Sir (Ernest) Edward `Weary' Dunlop, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent weeks, all Australians have mourned the loss of Sir Edward Weary Dunlop. He was 85. Through his work as a surgeon in prisoner of war camps in Asia during the Second World War, and through his postwar work assisting veterans and his efforts in strengthening the relationship between Australia and Asia, Weary Dunlop was a figure not just honoured and revered in this country but also, I think it is fair to say, genuinely loved by his fellow Australians.

PARA.TAB: He was born into a farming family in northern Victoria in 1907. After an active and happy childhood, he gained qualifications in both pharmacy and medicine. His student days in Melbourne were full to the brim, as he was also a brilliant sportsman, becoming a champion at boxing and rugby union. He was in London undertaking postgraduate work in surgery when the war began. He loved his work, but the outbreak of war made life at St Mary's Hospital, Paddington, seem like a `charmed circle', as he put it. By pulling some strings he managed to enlist in the 2nd AIF from London, and was posted directly to Jerusalem in November 1939 with the rank of captain.

During his two years in the Middle East, his appetite for adventure meant that he was rarely far from the centre of action. He served in Libya, Greece and Crete, and volunteered for service with the Australian Casualty Clearing Station in besieged Tobruk. He declined command of that unit, preferring to retain the surgical post of major. On his way back to Australia with the 7th Division, his ship was diverted to Java in a desperate bid to stem the Japanese move southward. He was taken prisoner of war in February 1942. He was moved to Batavia, Singapore, and finally to Konyu camp along the route of the now notorious Burma-Thailand railway.

At Konyu, and at further camps along the line, Dunlop and his fellow prisoners faced some of the most appalling conditions ever experienced by Australians at war. Men were daily forced out to work, clearing the jungle to make way for the railway. Malaria, dysentery, tropical ulcers, cholera and beri-beri were common, exacerbated by malnutrition and brutal punishment by Japanese and Korean guards.

Time and again, Sir Edward Dunlop intervened to stop desperately sick men being forced to work. He fashioned surgical instruments and equipment from whatever was at hand and operated on his patients by oil light. He used all his wiles to obtain food and drugs. He saw his men out in the morning and was there to greet them when they arrived back exhausted in the evening.

He was often sick himself and was punished, and three times he was threatened with execution for his intercession on behalf of the sick. Although forbidden to do so, he kept a radio and a detailed diary. His experience as a prisoner fostered in him insights into humanity that shaped the rest of his life. In his diary he allowed himself only snatches of despair and ill feeling towards the Japanese.

In May 1943, he admitted to a `searing hate', as he expressed it, arising in him whenever he saw a Japanese. He was as capable of hatred as he was of love, but ultimately he could not suppress from developing a deep compassion for the Japanese when he understood the wretchedness of their position at the end of the war. At the end of his war diary he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: This has been a war against monstrous things, but one for which we all share responsibility because of the selfish pre-occupations which allowed matters to reach such hideous proportions.

He resolved then to make the welfare of ex-prisoners of war a lifetime mission. In the postwar years, as he rose to prominence as a surgeon in Melbourne, he was tireless in the service of his former comrades, active in prisoner of war associations and once again intervening on their behalf whenever he could. Many former prisoners of war found him an active champion in handling the complexities of repatriation.

PARA.TAB: At the same time, he lacked any sense of bitterness or desire for recriminations against the Japanese. Instead, he set about promoting links between Australia and Asia, and with Japan in particular. He was active in the health program sponsored under the Colombo Plan initiated by Australia in 1950 to promote cooperation with, and assistance to, South East Asia.

In 1969 he led an Australian medical team into South Vietnam to provide care for civilians injured in the war. Honours were heaped on him in Australia and overseas, particularly in Thailand and Sri Lanka. He was made a knight bachelor in 1969, Australian of the Year in 1976 and a Companion of the Order of Australia in 1987.Through it all he remained essentially a very humble man and, like many ex-service people, not necessarily very comfortable in talking about his wartime experiences.

In the tributes that have been paid to him since his death so many people have remembered his unfailing ability to see some good in everyone, including his enemies. It was that ability that drove his courage, his sense of duty and his capacity to forgive.

With his great love and understanding of humanity, Sir Edward Weary Dunlop will be very sadly missed probably not simply by his family, most especially, and his friends, but by those with whom he maintained associations after the war, by those with whom he was a prisoner of war and for whom he was a leader. I know that a number of them are in the gallery today, including a former member of this House, the former honourable member for Reid, Tom Uren, who also served under Sir Edward Dunlop as a prisoner of war on the Burma-Thailand railway. I know that on the day of his funeral service in Melbourne so many of the people with whom he had served as a prisoner of war were there at the cathedral. They had obviously kept in contact with him and will miss him most sincerely. On behalf of the government, I extend our sincere sympathy to his family in its bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. It is right that this national parliament should recognise and honour the life and work of Sir Edward Weary Dunlop. I am very pleased to support what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has just said about a truly great Australian. We mourn the passing of Weary Dunlop because of who he was, because of what he achieved and because of the sense of community which inspired all that he did.

PARA.TAB: With his death on 2 July, Australia lost one of its finest citizens and one of its greatest heroes. His contribution to our national life was unique. In all he did—as a scholar, as a sportsman, as a soldier, as a surgeon, as a community leader, and as a husband and father—Weary Dunlop brought an uncompromising commitment to human dignity, a faith in the ultimate power of what is right and the pursuit of excellence in the service of the common good.

Weary Dunlop, of course, fought many battles in his life. He fought disease and suffering; he fought unfairness and injustice; he fought impoverishment of the human spirit and he fought a brutal enemy in a war that preyed on both the minds and the bodies of those who endured it. In all of these battles Weary Dunlop faced enormous odds, and in all of them he triumphed—not in any way that craved popular acclaim, but in a quiet, self-effacing manner that was his hallmark.

His gifts and his compassion for all people were matched only by his modesty. During the Second World War his leadership and care of allied prisoners of war became a legend. On the Burma-Siam railway Sir Edward became a byword for courage, for compassion and for skill in the face of almost unimaginable cruelty and despair. As human suffering, disease and a sense of hopelessness threatened to consume everything, Weary Dunlop shone like a light in the darkness. One of his fellow prisoners of war, Donald Stuart, put it best years after the war when he wrote of Weary Dunlop in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: When despair and death reached for us he stood fast, his only thought our well-being. Faced with guards who had the power of life and death, ignoble tyrants who hated us, he was a lighthouse of sanity in a universe of madness and suffering.
Another wrote that Sir Edward was like a mountain—the further you got away from him, the bigger you realised he was.

PARA.TAB: Weary Dunlop lifted spirits as much as he alleviated physical suffering. He inspired broken men and he drew his own inspiration from them. He healed broken bodies, despite the absence of proper medical supplies and proper medical instruments. For those whom he could not heal, he at least gave some dignity in death. He achieved these things and so much more in the most appalling and the most degrading of circumstances, and he did so in a way that epitomised what is best in the Australian character—defiance against the odds, mateship, resolve and faith in the future.

A story told by Dr Max Lake about Weary Dunlop typifies, I believe, many of his qualities. The story goes as follows: Weary discovered a man tampering with his car. When challenged, the man made his first mistake by taking off, because Weary had a blue for running. He made his second mistake by trying to dodge, because Weary was a football blue and he tackled him. He made his final and most serious mistake by shaping up and having a go. Weary had a blue for boxing and he broke his jaw. Weary then gathered him up, drove him to the hospital, set his jaw and arranged for the discharge and review of the patient at the next convenient outpatient clinic.
After the war Sir Edward continued the physical care and moral support of those with whom he had shared so much. Like Tennyson, who was a poet he much admired, Sir Edward could truly say:

SPEECH.PARA: I am a part of all that I have met.

Weary Dunlop never forgot the past and all who shared its sacrifices with him. But he always looked to the future—a future full of promise, hope and faith in the human spirit. He always valued what he described as the timeless, enduring, special brotherhood that was shared with all survivors of prison camps. He never became vindictive, though few men had more reason to be so. He always remained inspired by what he once described as a belief that all the races of mankind bear some special mark of God's tenderness, some unique contribution to humankind.

PARA.TAB: The range of his postwar interests was testimony to the breadth of his vision and his compassion. He worked tirelessly for many causes associated with the welfare of his fellow citizens, including health care for the aged, medical research, the Anti-Cancer Council, ex-servicemen's associations, the Council for the Welfare of Overseas Students and, of course, relations with countries of the Asia-Pacific region generally.

Sir Edward Dunlop received many awards and many honours for his life's work, but his greatest memorial lies in the special place he holds in the hearts and minds of those with whom he shared his life. It was Tennyson who wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Tho' much is taken, much abides.

What has been taken from us is Sir Edward's physical presence. What abides is his spirit, the enduring achievements of his life's work and the deep respect and affection with which his memory is honoured in Australia and in many other countries. In his war diaries, Sir Edward noted:
In the annals of human suffering, Australians had written something very special of their own, and handed on a precious legacy to the future.

Sir Edward Weary Dunlop has handed on to future generations of Australians his own very precious legacy. His life and work, his sense of duty and his compassion for his fellow human beings will always be an inspiration to Australians and to men and women right around the world.

PARA.TAB: I join wholeheartedly with the Prime Minister in what he has said today about Sir Edward Weary Dunlop. On behalf of the coalition parties, I support the motion before the House and I extend my deepest sympathy to Sir Edward's family and to his many friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a privilege to speak in support of this motion of condolence in relation to Sir Edward Weary Dunlop—a warrior on many fronts, a man who wrought many medical wonders and miracles, an extraordinary hero. As the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) have said, yet at the end of the day, Sir Edward was a humble, generous and truly courageous man.

PARA.TAB: I place on the dispatch box a section of the Burma Death Railway, or Burma-Thailand Railway, as a particular mark of respect to someone who did so much to ease the burden of so many in acts of heroism, day after day, as the work proceeded on this railway line through terrible terrain and in horrific conditions. The Australian-Thailand Chamber of Commerce presented this section of line to me. It comes from near Nam Tok and Konyu Cutting and near the Hell Fire Pass Memorial, which is attracting more attention each Anzac Day in Thailand. I commend a visit to those honourable members who are able to do so. They will see first hand a section of the Burma Death Railway, the setting of that Konyu Cutting or Hell Fire Pass, and will begin to appreciate the agony and horrific circumstances that faced so many prisoners of war during World War II.

To walk through Konyu Cutting even on a hot Thailand day seems to chill one to the bone on the steep side of the valley, as the line climbs from Nam Tok to Bagodars Pass and on into Burma. Former members of this parliament—Tom Uren, who is in the gallery today, and Sir John Carrick—along with thousands of other prisoners of war, toiled in those extremely harsh conditions along the line. They suffered from sickness, from injuries due to bashings by the guards, and a range of other factors.

In all of this turmoil, Sir Edward Weary Dunlop showed great leadership, great surgical skills and a great capacity in his work as a doctor in very trying circumstances, at times risking his own life in standing up for the regime. He was the recipient of many bashings by Korean and Japanese guards and, worse still, he faced an execution countdown on at least two occasions. I will quote a short, chilling extract from page 303 of the war diaries of Weary Dunlop:

SPEECH.PARA: At last I was told patience was now exhausted and I must die. I was pushed and flogged along to a tree and my manacles changed to encircle my wrists behind the tree with my body and arms taut about the tree, my bare belly exposed to four bayonets wielded by an execution squad of four, making the characteristic belly grunting, blood-curdling yells, working themselves up to `the moment'.

I was told by the interpreter—the one in the party with long hair—that I was to have the grace of 30 seconds, which were grimly counted in Japanese. My eyes were locked on the flinty, impassive face of the `interrogating' officer. Strange thoughts flitted through my mind.

The egregious voice of the interpreter—`Now ten seconds to go. Have you last message for relatives. I shall try to convey'. I shifted my gaze to his distasteful face and said contemptuously: `Last message conveyed by thugs like you—no thanks!' The bayonets were withdrawn and poised for the last yelling thrust when I saw a flush on the face of my executioner who raised a hand and cried, `Stop! He will suffer a lot more than this before he dies—untie him!' The manacles were transferred to the front and I suffered a bout of heavy beating without further interrogation.

This man, Sir Edward Weary Dunlop, had nearly another two years in captivity after that particular incident but he continued his work. He continued to provide his leadership, helping hundreds upon hundreds of prisoners of war in those trying circumstances in Thailand.

PARA.TAB: Let me just add two other aspects in relation to his war efforts. Firstly, Sir Edward saw extensive service in other theatres of war even before reaching Asia. In 1940 he was posted to Jerusalem, Palestine, Greece, Crete and Tobruk. As the Prime Minister said, Sir Edward arrived in Java on 17 February 1942, already having given adequate and capable service in World War II in the European and Middle East theatres of war. He was promoted to command No. 1 Allied General Hospital. At capitulation, Sir Edward Weary Dunlop elected to stay with his hospital and patients and become a prisoner of war.

Secondly, he returned to Asia in the 1960s, at some risk, as a man who had seen so much. He returned as a team leader with the Australian surgical team in the Vietnam War, caring for civilians—the Vietnamese—and Australian soldiers. However, there are other aspects of his extraordinary life which point to his ability against all odds.

In this context, on a lighter note, I refer to the fact that he was selected for, and played in, the Australian rugby team of the 1930s. That is significant enough, some might argue, but, even more significantly, he achieved this selection as a person born in Victoria and as a student of Melbourne University—a long way from the power houses of rugby in Sydney and Brisbane. I think honourable members will concede that that is no mean feat. Interestingly, he wore the test rugby guernsey or jumper when taken to hospital the last time. I quote from the eulogy by Dr Donaldson at St Paul's Cathedral in Melbourne:
`Weary' arrived at that heavenly playing field dressed to play the game.

SPEECH.PARA: To all of this I might also add that Sir Edward Weary Dunlop made a point of coming all the way to the small town of Jerilderie in my electorate on Australia Day 1988, the bicentennial year, to deliver a fine address in the searing heat of the late afternoon of a Riverina summer's day. He received many accolades on that occasion, as he deserved to. But he thought not much of the effort and he was very happy to be there. Nothing was too small or too large for Weary Dunlop to contribute to or play a key role in, as the ever helpful person he was.

PARA.TAB: To members of the Dunlop family, to the ex-servicemen's community, and particularly to ex-prisoners of war, I extend my sympathy on behalf of the National Party of Australia and on behalf of my colleagues. I strongly support the comments of the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. As a Vietnam veteran, I salute Sir Edward Weary Dunlop for all he did in service to his country and in service to mankind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to support the condolence motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I also support the remarks made by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer). I had the pleasure of meeting with Sir Edward—more affectionately known as Weary—Dunlop during my term of office as Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Weary was a marvellous man and somebody that I will never forget. I have had the pleasure of meeting many distinguished servicemen and women over the years that I was the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, including some very highly decorated Australians. I know they will forgive me for saying today that Sir Weary to me was the one veteran above all others who captured my never ending admiration and total respect.

PARA.TAB: He always assisted me and the Department of Veterans' Affairs when asked to do so. I know that Secretary Tanzer, Secretary Woodward and all the people in the Department of Veterans' Affairs had the greatest admiration for Weary Dunlop. I want to place that on record here today. I remember the occasion when we went to Heidelberg Repatriation Hospital for a health week campaign for the veterans of Heidelberg. We had had a good talk to them when Weary turned up. It was a medi-dump campaign to make sure the veterans were getting rid of all their old pharmaceuticals that were out of date. Weary spoke to them in that regard and told them that they should not have their medications for too long; that they should get rid of them and hand them in at the hospital.

Afterwards we had a lovely afternoon tea and a progressive barn dance. All the ladies and war widows lined up to dance with Weary—and I also danced. I did not do the quickstep, but I have to admit that I had to sit down before Weary. I tried to find out why they called him Weary Dunlop. I thought it must be `Time shall not weary them' because he just kept working on behalf of the veterans community. But it was something to do with Dunlop tyres and weary Dunlop tyres or something like that. I will not say any more about that and condemn the Dunlop tyres of the day.

In all those years as Minister for Veterans' Affairs and in going to many POW celebrations and commemorations, not once at all the different conferences or functions did I hear anybody say a bad word about Weary Dunlop. And I must say, as far as I can remember, Weary Dunlop never said a bad word about anybody. He only once challenged me, saying, `Look, you shouldn't be making these cutbacks in the veterans' affairs portfolio'. I said, `I don't believe that we've done that, Weary, but if you can show me where I'll be happy to correct that'.

Not only was Weary on my back in those days but also I can remember the day Tom Uren—it is good to see Tom here today—was in the office with the Prime Minister, who was then the Treasurer. Tom was making sure that in the budget that was coming up we did the right thing on behalf of the POWs—especially the POWs. Tom always spoke on behalf of all veterans, just as Weary did.

I checked up through the department on a few figures today. Weary was one of 22,376 Australian POWs in 1942. Three years later there were 14,345, and Weary was one of them. That was the number repatriated. I know that a lot of them owe a great debt of gratitude not only to Weary but also to all the other doctors that were there working on behalf of those veterans. There were many others. I saw a letter in the newspaper one day saying that Weary was not the only doctor in the POW camps, but it would be fair to say that Weary stood out amongst all of them, although I know Weary never thought he was any better than anybody else.

Most of us went to Weary's state funeral. I must congratulate everyone in the protocol department that took part in organising that funeral. I was very moved by the sermon of the Reverend Dr James Donaldson and the eulogy of Sir Ninian Stephen. I should like to quote from them, so I know all honourable members will bear with me. It is not very often that one can sit through sermons and enjoy them. I must admit that, as the minister of the day, I did not realise what a great person Weary Dunlop was until I went to the funeral. I knew a lot about him but not enough. The Reverend Donaldson said:

As we come to honour such a great man today let us briefly take these two aspects of Weary's life namely, (1) the capacity to forget ourselves and our own needs in order to serve others, and (2) the capacity to forgive and bring about reconciliation and apply both of these to our own lives in Australia today. Would not this great country of Australia be a much better land if each of us could forget our own needs and think of the needs of others? Would not our community be much better off if our leaders in every sphere of life in church, in community, in commerce and in politics were humble, selfless and inspiring, rather than to be power hungry and manipulative? Would not our country reach its great potential if we all displayed the kind of compassion the kind of love the kind of sacrificial service that Sir Edward Dunlop showed is clearly possible for each one of us?

If that kind of man can come out of Sheepwash Creek, Stewarton (and how Australian that is, the man who came from Sheepwash Creek) what kind of men and women can come out of any place in Australia Wangaratta, or Bathurst, or Adelaide, or Kalgoorlie or Port Douglas? If we were prepared to use our talents and capacities for the welfare and betterment of others in this fantastic Australia that we call home.

SPEECH.PARA: I now quote from Sir Ninian Stephen:

Bitterness never entered his soul, for he knew its corroding influence and forthrightly rejected it. Instead he gathered the strength to feel Christian forgiveness of the enemy, that coming to him, he said, at war's end when, seeing a wounded Japanese soldier slumped down on the floor of a railway truck full of Japanese prisoners and apparently in danger of being crushed, he went to help him up. Weary took him by the shoulders to lift him, only to find him dead. With that all hatred of the enemy died too.
It is a pity that Weary was not with us recently when the new Prime Minister of Japan apologised for Japanese atrocities during World War II.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, I have no doubt that Weary's name will live on. I know that the Prime Minister, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and all others will give help to the Sir Edward Dunlop Medical Research Foundation. Sir Edward believed that insufficient medical research had been devoted to the needs of ageing veterans. In his later years he made representations for further research which, in his vision, would subsequently benefit the ageing population in the community at large. This vision was taken up with the Department of Veterans' Affairs by the Veterans Affairs Coordinating Council of Organisations in Victoria, and culminated in the incorporation of the Sir Edward Dunlop Medical Research Foundation as a public company in May 1987.

The foundation has a national role of funding research and was a joint venture between the Department of Veterans' Affairs and ex-service organisations in Victoria. While it operates independently, accommodation and administration support are provided by the department in furthering the foundation's work. The main objection of the foundation, endorsed by Sir Edward, is stated as being:

SPEECH.PARA: To do and undertake all things necessary for, or tending towards or likely to promote the maintenance and improvement of the medical and similar care of veterans and their dependants, their health and general welfare.
I support the motion and offer my sympathies and those of my family to Sir Edward's family and all their friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the bells of St Paul's cathedral in Melbourne tolled their tribute, and the solitary lament of a Scottish piper broke the air, the Australian nation paid tribute to Sir Edward Weary Dunlop—sportsman, war surgeon, soldier, medical ambassador and special friend and advocate to Australia's POWs. There were many young people standing outside St Paul's cathedral that day, and many commentators drew attention to that fact. Jack Flannery, Weary Dunlop's driver for 43 years, was not at all surprised. Jack said that during the 43 years he drove Weary, visiting hundreds of small country towns, Weary always made a special point of stopping and talking to children. He used to tell them what it was like for him as a young boy growing up in the country. He was always interested in their hopes and aspirations and he would almost invariably turn to Jack and say, `Those children are our heritage; we must look after them'.

PARA.TAB: That oft repeated statement of his gives us an insight into the thinking of this great man. He was imbued with a sense of duty and responsibility from an early age. His training as a surgeon reinforced that sense of responsibility, but it was always tempered with a sense of dignity and humanity and always with an eye to the future. It was John Kennedy who said that courage was a mixture of triumph and tragedy; that a man does what he must in spite of personal consequences and in spite of obstacles and dangers; and that courage in one person seems to inspire others and offer hope. I believe that description aptly defines the actions and strengths of Weary Dunlop.

There have been numerous accounts of the selfless actions of Weary in saving the lives of his fellow POWs on the Burma railway: his willingness to withstand torture and gross deprivation to benefit others; his ingenuity in utilising whatever primitive materials were at hand as surgical instruments; and his tireless efforts as an advocate, not just for food and medical supplies but also for human dignity. In acknowledging these actions of Weary Dunlop and honouring him, we too honour a long line of Australian war surgeons who also displayed extraordinary courage. In order to understand what Weary himself endured, I would like to quote from his war diaries of July 1945:
They belaboured me with rifle butts, chairs, boots.

Eventually I was motionless beyond resistance, lying face down in the dust, conscious of broken ribs and blood from scalp wounds. I was gathered up, dazed and rubber-limbed, and trussed and roped backward kneeling with a large log between my seat and knees. As my head cleared there was intolerable pain due to rough ground pressure on the knees and the weight and pressure of the log. Breathing was sharply painful with fractured ribs, slowly the pain ceased in my legs because they had no circulation. How long to gangrene in the tropical heat?

As the sun became low there was at last a final summing up. "Out of bed days after lights out, some days late to report to guard, and finally guilty of appalling, heinous insolence to guard. If we were so forgiving as to release you, would you have hard feelings against the guard?" I considered this cautiously and replied: "Hard feelings against what guard?

This was apparently accepted as a more reasonable attitude. My ropes were released. Slowly, painfully, with the return of circulation, I found I could move my legs and feel my feet again. At last, a little drunkenly, I was on my feet again. I stood to attention, bowed and said: "And now if you will excuse me I shall amputate the Dutchman's arm who's been waiting all day." I was determined to show them that Australians were tough!

SPEECH.PARA: Weary's work for POWs, however, did not cease when peace was finally declared. Troops were demobbed and returned home to start afresh. The injuries sustained throughout that period, and the indelible effect of the POW camps on the minds and bodies of thousands of ex-servicemen, meant that their struggle for survival continued long after they returned to the security of their families.

PARA.TAB: As so many ex-servicemen have said, just as their problems continued so did Weary's work for them in trying to make governments and bureaucrats understand, whether that be in gaining medical attention or eligibility for a pension. As one old digger said to me, `He knew what we went through because he went through it too'. Weary was determined to achieve recognition for the ordinary men and women who served their country with honour but were often faced with hostility when trying to establish that they now needed assistance due to the results of the injuries they suffered in the service of their country.

Weary revealed many of these experiences in his war diaries, and I think we can understand his continued sense of responsibility to those former POWs when he referred to the timeless, enduring, special brotherhood shared by all survivors of prison camps. I think it is pertinent today that two former POWs and former members of this House, Clarrie Millar and Tom Uren, have come to listen to this condolence motion. It was Indira Gandhi who said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are moments in history when brooding tragedy in its dark shadows can be lightened.

Weary Dunlop perhaps lightened those brooding tragedies of Japanese POW camps by being an active participant in building bridges into Asia throughout his involvement in the development of Australia's role in the Colombo Plan, and was active in his role as an ambassador of Australia through exchange of knowledge and culture with Asia—in particular, Malaysia, Sri Lanka, Thailand and India. He became President of the Australian-Asian Association of Victoria and led an Australian surgical team to Vietnam in 1969. Dr David Kings, Weary's personal doctor and family friend, said of his friend:
It was my impression that his greatest raison d'etre in recent years was to make Australia fit in and work with Asia. He was doing that long before anyone else stood up and did it.

Weary Dunlop has been rightly described as an Australian hero. At a time in our history when as a nation we are examining our national identity, it is fitting that a man who put his own life at risk to protect others, who used his medical and surgical skills to repair the physical and mental damage inflicted by war, and always believed in a better future, should today be a hero for our young generation. I extend my sympathy to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew Weary Dunlop very slightly, although I saw him often as he sloped round the plaster of paris end of Collins Street, or in book shops, or as he drove, Fangio-like, hat pulled down to his ears, in his battered white Mercedes between Toorak Road and the city. One element was missing, I thought, in the eulogies at his state funeral in St Pauls Cathedral, eloquent and deeply felt as they were, and it was the point brought out by our former colleague Tom Uren in his tribute in the Australian and on AM: the model of cooperative leadership that Sir Edward Dunlop evolved at the Kintok prisoner of war camp on the Burma-Thailand railway. Under the Geneva convention, officers, medical orderlies and prisoners able to work received a small wage.

PARA.TAB: In the Kintok camp, the bulk of allowances were paid into a central fund, which was used to buy drugs and food for the very needy and the sick. Under Colonel Dunlop's inspired leadership, the camp adopted some important principles: the fit looking after the sick, the young looking after the old and the collectivisation of incomes. It was a model of a society which worked on the principles of cooperation, mutual dependence, shared experience and respect for heroic leadership.

The medical record, set out as appendix III of his great book The War Diaries of Weary Dunlop, indicates the extraordinary success of his leadership. In the table of Australian patients admitted to his working camp hospitals—seven in all—between June 1942 and October 1943, only 83 deaths occurred out of 5,664 patients; that is less than 1.5 per cent. There would be a bigger death rate than that in some civilian hospitals. Of those 83 deaths, 63 came from a cholera outbreak. The record is quite phenomenal: less than 1.5 per cent of those people admitted. Other units with leadership of a lesser quality than Dunlop's had far higher death rates.

The book is a great contribution to Australian history and also to Australian literature. He refused to publish the diaries for 40 years and printed his entries as he wrote them, resisting the temptation, which all of us have from time to time, to improve the writing. I want to quote words that he wrote and Sir Laurens van der Post's words in his introduction, which epitomises his spirit. Referring to the time that they had handcarts bringing in purchases from the Chinese, Sir Laurens wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The handwagons were barely through the gates when a private rushed out of the Guardroom, halted them and declared that he would summon the Corporal of the Guard to conduct a search of our supplies. Our Chinese providers had grown so careless that we could see, through the ragged screen of fruit and vegetables, shining streaks of the deep red-brown sides of another mahogany radio cabinet. If the Japanese found, as they could not fail to, the radio among our supplies, it would mean not only the end of a vital source of food, but judging by what had happened in other camps, the execution of the people concerned in the smuggling of the radios. Weary, seeing that the Guard had his back turned to him in hurrying up to the office where the Corporal and rest of the Guard were sitting in comfort, instantly walked up to the relevant handcart and whisked out the cabinet radio. He did it as lightly and easily as if he were merely extracting a rugby football from another ruck on an international rugger ground where he had played for Australia . . . He tucked it under his arm and proceeded to walk smartly past the Guard towards the prison hospital. I followed him as fast as I could. I saw a sleepy corporal coming out of the room, stopping him, and in the rudest of Japanese demanding to know what he carried under his arm.

PARA.TAB: `Medical supplies,' Weary answered, with a ring of authority in his voice that was so irresistible that the moment I translated for the corporal, adding that he was the doctor in charge of the sick people in the hospital, the corporal waved us on and the incident was closed. But it could easily have been the end of Weary as well as some half dozen of the rest of us.

SPEECH.PARA: He later writes about farewelling Weary Dunlop when he left Java:

. . . I think back to that walk and that moment when Weary, undismayed and even at so gloomy an hour, extracting a laugh from his overburdened men, met us at the great gate, all the adjectives personified in the Pilgrim's Progress and so unfashionable today occur to me as the only ones precise enough for the occasion; adjectives like `valiant', `standfast', `tell-true', `great-heart' and so on, but also joined to those some not to be found in Bunyan's vocabulary, like Weary's unfailing sense of humour and his light and classical use of irony as a means of defeating self-pity and reducing the intrusions of fate in the life of himself and of those under his command to bearable human proportions.
Weary Dunlop wrote about his attitude towards the Japanese and the Germans:

PARA.TAB: In Japan there is much of sensitivity and creativity, but I have sensed that the single-minded loyalty gives the system some of the defects of an insect society, with a pattern of blind, unswerving acceptance of leadership whether towards good or evil.

This, too, marches with the Germanic brooding madness of the Gotterdammerung, `The Twilight of the Gods', with desperate overtones of self-immolation. It is difficult for those of such intensity of purpose to temper their actions or to direct humour to them.

SPEECH.PARA: As Sir Ninian Stephen said of Sir Edward in his funeral oration:
With perhaps only Douglas Mawson, of all Australians, he shares a lone eminence of sustained heroism and superb achievement.
No tribute can go higher than that. I join with other members of the House in expressing sympathy to the Dunlop family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House expresses its deep regret at the death on Friday, 30 July 1993, of the Hon. From 1962 to 1965 he held the position of government whip.

PARA.TAB: In 1967 Sir Condor entered the federal parliament as senator for South Australia. His time in the Senate was characterised by his good humour and unfailing good nature towards his colleagues on both sides of the chamber. It was these qualities that led to his election as President of the Senate in 1976. He filled this position with distinction until his retirement in 1981. He was noted and praised for his honesty and sense of fair play. He was temporary chairman of committees from 1969 to 1972 and served on several committees—including the Joint Committee on the New and Permanent Parliament House, of which he was joint chairman. I served on that committee with him myself for about seven years. I can attest very closely to the fact that he was a person of honesty with a great sense of fair play. He was a very good President. In his time as President, the disruptions and namings were very few and far between. As I have said, he was very warmly regarded by all senators.

There is one other reason why I wanted to put a couple of things on the record. It is something that I think few, if any, other members of this chamber would be aware of and that is the role that he played—he took it very seriously—in relation to all members of parliament as part of his responsibilities as a presiding officer.

As you are aware, Mr Speaker, it is traditional that the Speaker is chairman of the Joint House Committee. In those days that committee played a very active role, or tried to, in relation to the general welfare of members, not just the dining rooms, as it tends to these days. A very difficult situation arose, to the point where very few meetings of the committee were being called. Some internal politics were being played in the Joint House Department. People running it were not particularly well motivated towards members but they liked the positions they occupied and the salaries that came with those positions.

It was only thanks to Sir Condor Laucke that members got any facilities. There was a move abroad to reduce very basic facilities. I refer to such very basic things as being able to buy a breakfast in Parliament House. For many members who stay in motels or in individual accommodation, it was only because Condor Laucke was approachable on the subject of members' amenities, always took them very seriously and tried to do his best towards their basic amenities, that they were preserved. As I said, we should bear in mind that he was not chairman of the Joint House Committee and that he did this from a position of some disadvantage. But he did care about every member of parliament and he cared about their problems.

I should like to say a brief word for Rose Laucke too. Not everybody is aware that Rose had been quite an outstanding ballerina when Condor met her. She was quite short but by the time that I met her she was not exactly sylph-like. But she was a wonderful person; she bubbled with warmth and personality. In many ways she was a great foil for Condor who was not an overly-serious man but who was a very much more reserved person than she was. She bubbled with warmth and love and they were both very warmly regarded by all who knew them. Condor clearly adored her, and she also adored `my Condor', as she used to refer to him.

Over the distance of the years—and I regret that it is a rather longer time since I have seen Condor Laucke than it is for the honourable member for Wakefield—I would like to add my tribute to a man who was an outstanding parliamentarian.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to pay tribute to the life of Sir Condor Laucke. As others have said, Sir Condor had a very distinguished career. He was a member of the South Australian Parliament, representing his beloved Barossa Valley; he was a senator from 1967 to 1981; he was President of the Senate for a while; and he was Lieutenant-Governor of South Australia.

PARA.TAB: Despite the high offices that Sir Condor held, he was however a man who always managed to retain a sense of perspective, and for that I must say I greatly admired him. He retained a humility and an understanding of where he himself fitted into the general plan of life rather than becoming overwhelmed with his own self-importance emanating from positions that he held. Many people in South Australia who knew him so well admired him for those qualities.

As others have mentioned, he also brought to public life the very greatest of values, and that was the value of integrity. I think I could say that Sir Condor was the most honest man I have ever known. He was always a man of his word; he was always a man who meant what he said. He also had very great respect for the institution of parliament, and others have said a good deal about that as well.

I know that Sir Condor always appreciated the tremendous support given to him throughout his public life as well as in his private life by Lady Laucke. Without the tremendous support of Lady Laucke, he would never have been able to achieve the things that he did achieve. I also appreciate very much the kindness that Sir Condor showed towards me on many occasions during preselections and other vital moments like that that really matter to all of us in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —You just said he was a man of very sound judgment.

—Sir Condor was of very great support to me and, as the Minister for Employment, Education and Training points out, was always a man of very sound judgment. I extend my deepest sympathy to Lady Laucke and to their children.

—Sir Condor Laucke was a very meticulous member of the Playford administration, and it was there that I first met him. It was apparent that his major concern was to see that those around him were comfortable in whatever social or business circle they were in. His concern for others was legendary. His security was the Barossa Valley, his family and his business.

PARA.TAB: I look back to those days in the state parliament with great memories. The security of his home and valley saw Condor through a number of difficult political circumstances—through the dying days of the Playford administration when a number of us, including Condor, were trying to change policies which otherwise were going to end in that government's defeat. During his time in the Senate—which has already been alluded to here—his home was his security.

Let us not forget that Condor also had a great sense of fun, something which is often lost sight of on these occasions. I used to sit behind him in the House of Assembly, and in those days he would meticulously write out everything he was about to say. But on a particular day this man of great moderation had his guard somewhat broken down by his friends. It was his birthday. He went to the milling association meeting in the morning and was treated by his friends with the products of the Barossa Valley. He came back to the house for lunch and was similarly treated—and through the afternoon and through dinner.

That evening he had to make a speech. I happened to be sitting opposite him, and I saw Condor in full flight for 20 minutes without a note. It was an amazing circumstance. He came to me the next day with the greatest of concern and said, `What did I say last night? Did I transgress?'. I said, `No, Condor, it was the greatest speech you have ever made'—and it was. I will not forget the mutual fun we all had about that.

Condor was a kindly, well based man who was very concerned with his state and with the job that he was doing. He brought those concerns to the federal parliament where, oddly enough, I again met him in the other house. I greatly admired his work in the South Australian community and in this parliament. Condor was a man of high ethical standards. He promoted those standards throughout the community and was an example to all who knew him. I extend my sympathies to his family. May I say, Mr Speaker, I was pleased to represent you at his funeral service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Much has been said of Condor Laucke and his qualities and his parliamentary contribution. I want to add several facets. With Condor's passing we have an ending of an era: Speaker Snedden has gone and President Laucke has gone. Those two, probably as much as anybody, were responsible for the advocacy that led the government of the day to decide on the move from the old temporary Parliament House.

PARA.TAB: There was one facet of the move which you, Mr Speaker, particularly enjoy. Condor enjoyed a far better dining table in the old place than Speaker Snedden. Speaker Snedden thought that there should be at least some equality of opportunity, and the facilities that you enjoy come in part from the generosity that Condor Laucke exercised as President of the Senate.

Much has been said of his quality. He was a tremendous fellow. I had a good deal to do with him in the development of what we now know as the income equalisation deposits scheme. If we look through Hansard, we will find that, as with drought bonds, it was one scheme that he advocated. He came from the small town of Greenock. Many of us come from rural Australia and we are conscious of the cycle of seasons. In Condor's maiden speech he urged—and subsequently as a senator and as a parliamentarian he frequently came to me to urge—the adoption of the scheme. It was partly from his advocacy, and that of some others, that the scheme which is still in place, though regrettably significantly modified, has been able to provide some help to successive generations of farmers.

Condor has been spoken of as a flour miller, a winegrower and a winemaker. Importantly, during the time I knew him, he recognised that others did not enjoy the affluence that he was able to achieve. When he took me to the Barossa Valley I was quite fascinated to learn of the German origins of many of the settlers. He spoke very strongly of those traditions which, in their diversity, are really what this country is all about. Condor was strongly in favour of helping those small wine grape growers who, for many years in South Australia, had extraordinary difficulty surviving. For as much as Condor made a success of his life, he was conscious that others had not.

The reflections on his wife, Rose Laucke, were such that she was brought strongly back to mind. She is a bubbling, effervescent personality. I must admit that her beginnings as a ballet dancer contrast markedly with the lady that I knew. She and Condor were a tremendous couple. The pair of them really contributed to the life of the old parliament. I know how much she will miss him because they were a great partnership. Certainly, between the two of them, they made an enormous contribution, not only to the Senate and the parliament, but also by representing South Australia in so many ways.
Like others before me, and on behalf of my own Rosemary, I would like to send our deepest sympathy to Rose and her family on the passing of a great Australian.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that the Prime Minister promised the Australian people tax cuts worth $8.6 billion in two instalments from 1 July 1994 and 1 January 1996? Is it also a fact that the Prime Minister told the National Press Club in February this year that his tax cuts were—and I quote—`not a promise; they are law, l-a-w, law'? —Order! The Leader of the Opposition will withdraw that last comment.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. There is a very conspicuous precedent in this parliament for the use of that expression, and in a far more offensive manner than was used by the Leader of the Opposition today. That was the use of the expression by the former Prime Minister in relation to his immediate predecessor. That is a precedent that has remained unrebuked by the action of this House since. The opposition regards the view that you are now taking in relation to the use of that word as being deliberately partisan.

—Order! In respect of the comment by the honourable gentleman, I have had the opportunity in the recess to reflect on the House of Representatives Practice—to which I would draw his attention also—as to rulings by previous speakers, particularly by Speaker Snedden, on this issue. I have found that on a number of occasions speakers have ruled that the use of that particular term, or any derivation of that term, is unparliamentary. As far as I am concerned, that will be the ruling that I uphold in this place.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the second and last part of your comment, if you have any particular objection to the ruling that has been so handed down, there are methods and forms of this House under which you may proceed. I invite the Leader of the Opposition to withdraw the last part of his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I withdraw and ask whether the Prime Minister will confirm that his promise was, in fact, a deliberate mistruth.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members—No!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I again go to the statement which I have just made, and that is that derivations of that same particular phrase will not be permitted in this House. Any repetition of the deliberate use of `lie', `misrepresentation', or whatever, will not be tolerated. I invite the Leader of the Opposition to rephrase his question.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The consistent practice in this place may well have been as you described it with respect to the first word to which you took objection. But it is not possible for members of this place to be denied the capacity to speak the truth. If you insist on the second interpretation, you are saying that it is not possible within this chamber to say that somebody else has said something which is not being sustained in practice. I ask you to consider carefully the consequences of what you say. While the first part of your determination may be correct, it is just not possible within the ambit of the English language for you to persist in the second requirement for the alternate form of words the Leader of the Opposition has asserted.

PARA.TAB: I would strongly put to you that if you wish this place to operate properly, you have to permit some reasonable variation or this place will become a farce, which I would suggest to you would be the result of that ruling.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would refer the right honourable gentleman to House of Representatives Practice again. I would also refer him to a number of cases where former speakers and, indeed, deputy speakers, have ruled in the way in which I have suggested. I have pointed out that the issue which I am particularly concerned about is the deliberate imputation of improper motives. Accordingly, it is my intention to rule that way. I invite the Leader of the Opposition to rephrase his question to reflect my ruling.
—Will the Prime Minister confirm that his promise was an attempt to mislead the people of Australia?

—The Leader of the Opposition is enjoying such an extravagant use of language these days. It rolls off his tongue with such ease in one press statement—blatheringly delivered—after another that he feels that this is par for the course for the parliament.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the tax cuts were promised in good faith and will be kept in good faith. They were promised in the One Nation statement of February 1992 to be delivered in 1994 and 1996, two years and four years from the date of the statements. At the time they were promised it was believed by the government and its advisers that the world was in a stronger position, and so was our growth.

As it turns out, the impact of the One Nation policy upon public demand and the economy has been most marked in the last 12 months. The delivery of the first stage of the tax cuts—in full, and early—will provide a needed stimulus to the economy in this particular year when demand has fallen off, when private consumption has been flat, and when the economy can do with a much needed further lift from the public sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Porkies, more porkies.
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders!
—Fancy his talking about porkies. My God! You are in the sin-bin. The Liberal Party should have put you in chains and kept you away. You are a menace.

PARA.TAB: When the legislation to introduce the tax cuts in 1994 and 1996 was scheduled, one expected the medium term trajectory of the budget's recovery to have been stronger. What the government is now doing is the sensible, the honourable, the decent and worthwhile thing; that is, delivering the first round of tax cuts in full, but bringing them on earlier and putting the second round later, so that the requirement of the budget to come back towards balance in the middle 1990s is improved, and then we will be delivering that which the government always intended would be delivered—the fiscal drag or tax indexation. Of course, the tax cuts would have been larger had it not been for the fact that inflation had fallen even further.

The government will deliver what it intended to deliver at the time of its announcement, with fiscal drag, and not more than full tax indexation over that period. It will deliver the tax cuts in this financial year, as taxpayers will see, in full. As well, it will at the same time meet another valid and important commitment to bring the deficit back to around one per cent of GDP in 1996-97—a commitment which is just as important to the nation as any other.
One would imagine, particularly from the hypocrisy of the honourable member for Flinders, of all people, who promised $12 billion worth of tax cuts—

TALK.START.PARA: —We were going to pay for it.

—You were not going to pay for a penny of it. The consumption tax proposal paid for the abolition of the wholesale sales tax, the abolition of payroll tax, and reductions in petrol tax, and nothing else—not one cent of tax cuts. Those opposite said they were going to cut $10,000 million out of outlays to a government which had taken outlays back to 24 per cent of GDP. It was the greatest con and fiddle in Australian federal political history. The Australian public spotted it in a second; they were onto it like a ton of bricks. That is why they dispensed with the services of the Leader of the Opposition and put him back in his place. The honourable member for Flinders is back on the back bench, where he well and truly belongs.

PARA.TAB: Let us be rid of this humbug that $12 billion worth of tax cuts from the coalition was to be funded by $10,000 million of cuts in government spending. Those opposite have got to be joking. How would they cut $10 billion out of outlays these days? They know what they would do; they would blow the budget to bits in 1996. What would those opposite do now that the growth has been lower and the budget balance has not returned as quickly as it would have in a cycle which was stronger? Had they won the 1993 election, what would they have done? Would they have delivered $12 billion worth of tax cuts when they could not cut outlays? No. They would have done what they did in 1976. They would have promised tax cuts in the 1977 election and then taken them back five months later. That is what they would have done. The public was right on to them.

Because the Liberals were running on a big tax policy, they assumed the Labor Party was running on an anti-tax policy. That is not so. We were running on a sensible tax policy. In this place one needs a memory. In the 1977 election, the public could ring the Liberals and find out what the tax cuts would be. The Liberals advertised their schedule of tax cuts in full page advertisements in the newspapers.

Well, there were no full page advertisements on the part of this government in the last election—so do not go trying to trump up a case that the last election was fought on tax cuts, because it was not. They were sitting in the One Nation package; they had been legislated—and they barely rated a mention in the campaign. What rated a mention was the stupidity of those opposite. That is why they are back where they belong.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Tourism. Can he advise the House as to whether there has been a significant increase in the number of international visitors coming into Australia and whether this boost to tourism has coincided with an increase in the marketing activities of the Australian Tourist Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lee The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the honourable member's question, yes, of course, there has been a very significant increase in the number of international travellers coming to Australia. That is why I was surprised to read in today's Australian the remarks of the new Chairman of the Queensland Tourist and Travel Corporation. While of course I hope that the Leader of the National Party of Australia might join me in congratulating Jim Kennedy on his appointment to the chair of the QTTC, and also acknowledge his past service as a board member on the ATC and the board of the QTTC, I have to take issue with Mr Kennedy's comment that, in his view, the ATC has failed to market Australia effectively overseas.

PARA.TAB: In fact, in 1992 we had a record 2.6 million international travellers coming to Australia. That was a 10 per cent increase on 1991 and that generated $8 billion in export earnings for Australia. This did not happen by chance and in 1991 there was a comprehensive evaluation of the marketing activities of the ATC. It found a very strong positive correlation between the markets where the ATC put in extra effort and where the extra international visitors came from. In fact, last year Australia's market share increased in over 11 countries.

Mr Kennedy has suggested that the effectiveness of the ATC is questionable because, in his opinion, few people in Hong Kong, Singapore or Taipei know about the Whitsundays.They may not know about the Whitsundays, but they certainly know about Australia because, if we look at the statistics for the first five months of this year compared with those of last year, the number of tourists from Hong Kong is up 22 per cent; from Singapore, up 44 per cent; and, from Taiwan, up 70 per cent. It is through the effective international promotion of Australia by the ATC that we have been able to achieve these sorts of increases. Of course, it is always interesting to remind the opposition that it has been during the life of the Hawke and Keating governments that funding for the ATC has increased eight-fold since 1983. Funding such as that has been able to help the ATC develop tactical campaigns throughout Asia to ensure that we are getting the right sorts of media campaigns in six languages in eight leading markets throughout the region.

If Queensland wishes to specifically promote the Whitsundays to these markets, I am sure that it will be pleased to know that this will soon be possible through a new marketing proposal known as partnership Australia, which has the strong support of the Prime Minister. Partnership Australia will encourage the states to coordinate with the ATC in tactical marketing campaigns aimed at distributing information about regions and holiday packages for not only the Whitsundays but also Far North Queensland and other parts of Australia of interest to my caucus colleagues. Partnership Australia will improve Australia's overall international marketing effort by reducing duplication and improving the effectiveness of federal and state overseas marketing campaigns. It will also ensure that we get more bang for every dollar that Australia is spending overseas promoting itself as a tourist destination.

Of course, international tourists do not recognise our state boundaries and I am concerned that we should not confuse them with some of the static that comes from competing federal, state and territory campaigns. It is for that same reason that I believe board members of the ATC should be appointed for their skills and expertise, not because of where they live. I have noticed that appointments to the QTTC have generated the same sort of geographical analysis as have appointments to the ATC and I share the view of the Queensland minister for tourism as reported in today's Australian. It stated:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . Mr Gibbs, dismissed the criticism as "stone age", saying any suggestion the board would favour one area over another was "grossly insulting" to its members.
I can assure the honourable member for Leichhardt that we will continue to ensure that we promote overseas all of Australia as a great tourist destination.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Just to jog his memory, did he say on the ABC's Lateline program on 19 November 1992, `What I am promising is not to put up tax'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The full sentence is:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . to maintain the tax to GDP ratios we roughly have at the moment. In other words, what I am promising is not to put up tax.
. . . to maintain the tax to GDP ratios we roughly have at the moment.

What we roughly have at the moment is something between 23.7 and 24.2 per cent of GDP. In 1991-92 it was 24.2 per cent of GDP and in 1992-93 it was 23.7 per cent. In other words, what I was promising to do was to maintain roughly those sorts of levels. I said exactly, `we roughly have at the moment'. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. In view of the recent growth performance of the Australian economy, and numerous announcements of new projects in the manufacturing sector, would the minister inform the House of the forecast pattern of Australian business investment?

—Like other South Australian government members, he has always shown a keen interest in the Australian industry sector and the automotive sector in particular. The Australian economy as a whole is seeing business investment show clear signs of a steady recovery as we move further into the growth phase of the business cycle. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures released for the June quarter yesterday show business investment in the manufacturing and mining sectors is up by five and eight per cent respectively. They also show—and I think importantly—improvement in the survey of business expectations of expenditure. That latter point is an interesting one in that, if one looks back, we have seen in the recent past better outcomes than in fact the business forecasts at the time were showing.

PARA.TAB: These survey results correspond to my own collection of anecdotal data during visits to various productive enterprises over the past few months. By way of example, I attended the furniture trades exhibition in Melbourne a week or so ago. I spoke to many of the small and medium sized business people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Higgins apparently regards the furniture trades sector as a laughing matter. It is an important sector of our economy and one that should not be treated with the scant regard that he is showing for it.

PARA.TAB: In discussions with many of the small business people who were around that exhibition, it appeared to me that there had been a considerable change in their circumstances relative to the previous year. That in fact was followed up by the furniture trades organisation writing to me and confirming that at the end of the exhibition those who had been participating—who reflected, I might say, the substantive proportion of that part of our business community—showed orders increasing over the previous year ranging from, at one level, 20 per cent to, more often, 100 per cent. Again, it is a straw in the wind—one would not want to make too much of it—but a very positive one indeed.

There is a whole series of other positive indicators. Honourable members will be aware of the proposed Coles Myer $4.1 billion investment program over the next four years. They would also be aware of the comments of Mr Bartels relating to the need for Australian chief executive officers to show a similar type of leadership. That one decision alone will lead to in the order of 140,000 jobs for our fellow Australians. BHP has made a whole series of announcements, including the $400 million new, world-scale blast furnace at Port Kembla and the $110 million rolling mill at the Sydney mini-mill. As I said, this is one positive indicator amongst many. In the automobile industry, again we have had very positive signs. Toyota has invested $420 million in its Altona plant—the construction of which, incidentally, came in under budget, within time and to technical specifications that Toyota has indicated to me are amongst the best in world.

The Mitsubishi motor company is also considering a very large investment—in the order of some $500 million—in a new engine and Magna model facility. In discussions with that company while I was in Japan a few short weeks ago, it indicated great interest in the Prime Minister's announcement that the development allowance would be extended to the automotive industry. This, of course, stands in stark contrast to the attitude of our opponents.

Mr Philip Brass, the chief executive officer of Pacific Dunlop—one of an increasing number of Australian business leaders who have made these comments—indicated that his company had correctly called the recession in 1989. He said a year ago that the recovery the analysts were speaking of was not evident but importantly—and we should take this in the manner in which it was given—`we are now saying things are coming off the bottom and recovering'.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it a fact that the government's campaign launch on 24 February 1993 contained a promise that Labor would remove all age pensioners from the tax system by 1995?

—The government has a commitment to review the interaction of the taxation and social security systems. Immediately after the election, the Treasurer stated that we would be having a look at that. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. I ask: can the minister inform the House of progress towards a national approach to coordinating what is taught in key school subjects across the country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Free The Hon R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fact that we do not have a national approach to what is studied in schools is a disgrace. A nation with half the population of California simply cannot hope to compete internationally with eight different sets of school curricula. A national approach seems to me to be a commonsense proposition, but I must say that not a lot of that commodity was on display at a meeting of state and federal education ministers held in Perth last month. The Perth meeting was scheduled to discuss how the states and territories could coordinate what is studied in eight key school subjects. Work to accomplish this has been carried out for five years by a committee of education experts drawn mainly from school systems in the states. That is

ANSWER.PARA: what that item was all about. However, ministers from some conservative states saw it as an opportunity to try to turn it into a states rights issue.

PARA.TAB: I point out that the Commonwealth has never driven this reform agenda. It is a state matter, and the coordination process enjoys bipartisan support from states such as Queensland and New South Wales. So the question for the Victorian and Western Australian ministers who led this charge of the intellectually lightweight brigade is really quite a simple one: when it comes to education, what is more important—empty rhetoric about states rights, or the rights of children? The people who would lose by the conservative mentality which suggests that there is no reason why states should cooperate with each other with regard to education are not the politicians—they are the kids. I hope that good sense will prevail.

The New South Wales government recently announced that the curriculum statements and profiles would go ahead in that state. I also hope that the Commonwealth's willingness to discuss specific educational, rather than petty political, concerns will ensure that we can get the process of national cooperation back on track. The state and federal ministers for education are scheduled to meet again in December, in Hobart. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I ask the Prime Minister: does he agree with the Minister for Employment, Education and Training that long-term unemployed people have as much hope of finding the Loch Ness monster as they do of getting a job?

—Mr Speaker, I wonder whether the honourable member for McPherson is referring to the same people the opposition proposes to tip off unemployment benefits after nine months. This Government has focused its labour market programs particularly on the long-term unemployed—those people who have been unemployed 12 months or more. They now number over 400,000 and, as honourable members will hear in tonight's budget, the government will be focusing on a very large proportion of those unemployed. A very high proportion of those long-term unemployed touched by those labour market programs will gain work experience and get back into the work force.

PARA.TAB: A feature of this period of unemployment is that there will be a greater number of long-term unemployed than there has been in the aftermath of other recessionary cycles. That is why the government has commissioned a study—a white paper—on employment and unemployment. It will be presented later in the year and may permit us to look at novel ways in which we can seek to redress some problems associated with the unemployed—particularly the long-term unemployed—so that these people are not carrying an undue burden resulting from Australia's economic change, its restructuring and its recovery. That is why we sought in the meantime to provide adequate income support and to particularly focus labour market programs on the long-term unemployed, which they are. If, as the coalition was seeking, $10,000 million were to be cut out of outlays, those labour market programs would have been cut to pieces—as indeed they would have been under its first policy position of taking people off unemployment benefits after nine months. Opposition members are entitled to talk in this Parliament about the unemployed, but not when their social security spokesman refers to them as riffraff and not when they were not prepared to support the unemployed in labour market programs and put the kind of budgetary support behind those people that they needed.

I said immediately after the election that this government would not be leaving the unemployed behind. I repeat that assertion: we will not be forgetting those who are unemployed, particularly those who are long-term unemployed. We will be seeking to devise the most innovative and far-reaching approaches to support those who are unemployed, and most particularly those who are long-term unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and concerns Australian involvement in the United Nations civilian police effort in Cambodia. Could the minister inform the House on the role played by the Australian Federal Police in Cambodia?

—The Australian Federal Police have been involved in Cambodia since May of last year. I might remind the House of the very significant work, spearheaded in particular by Senator Gareth Evans, in terms of the settlement we have been seeking to achieve to get a peaceful resolution to that unfortunate war-torn region.

PARA.TAB: The first contingent of 10 officers led by Superintendent Bill Kirk was posted to Thmar Puok in north-west Cambodia in the so-called liberated zone where all the factions, including the Khmer Rouge, operate. I might say by way of explanation that in this liberated zone there are essentially four armed forces each contesting, prior to the recent period of relative peace, for control of that sector. Each had its own military forces and into that environment the Australian Federal Police and the German and Tunisian police went. It certainly was a dangerous area and all of our contingents have been on heightened levels of alert all the time.

The Australian Federal Police when they arrived built a police station, a training school, and accommodation and recreation facilities. I suppose, in a lighthearted way, it certainly is the only flushing toilet that exists north of Phnom Penh.

The second group of Australian Federal Police led by Superintendent Bob Bradley took over the task in January of this year. It continued a training effort that has led to more than 400 Cambodians from all the factions, including the Khmer Rouge, being trained as police men and women.

The interesting thing about the training that the Australians have been able to achieve is that they have been able to bring together all the different factional groups, so not only have they trained those 400 police but also they have left, after their work, some 40 Cambodians who are ready to train others to continue the process of building a local police force.

The great success of their work has been that, in that region at least, we got the clear indication that all the different factions were prepared to unite their police services under a common command. That was the only area which was not under the control of the central government where such an outcome was achieved, notwithstanding the best efforts of the United Nations forces.

Recently, I had the very great privilege of being able to visit Thmar Puok and I saw at first-hand the work they had done. Afterwards when we came back to Phnom Penh, I was able to talk to the representatives of the Cambodian government, the UN special representative Akashi, General Sanderson and Police General Roos. They all said that the Australian Federal Police had been exceptional in their work and had been the best forces on the ground in Cambodia as part of the United Nations civilian police operations.

I believe all Australians can be very proud of the work that has been done by members of the Australian Federal Police. The Cambodian minister for justice said to me that they are now a permanent part of his country's history. I am sure that all members of the House would like to extend their congratulations to the Australian Federal Police for the hard work they have done under difficult conditions in the interests of our country.
