TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs. Has the minister's attention been drawn to criticisms by Russell Rollason, the Director of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, that our aid program is too commercially directed? What is his response to those criticisms?

—I thank perhaps my most distinguished predecessor in this portfolio for a question which has indeed been brought to my attention and I welcome the opportunity to respond to the criticisms which Russell Rollason and others in the NGO community have made.

PARA.TAB: It is simply not the case that the aid program which Australia maintains has fallen prey to, or been captured by, commercial interests. We do have a very significant development cooperation program—just how significant honourable members will find out tonight when it is revealed how well, in difficult times, the government has maintained its aid program.

Its motive is to improve the living standards in developing countries—particularly those in our own region. It is motivated primarily by the very real desire of all Australians to help improve the quality of life of people who are much less well off than ourselves. Those humanitarian motives are the main motivation for our aid program and without those motives the program would not exist. But we also recognise that in serving those fundamental humanitarian objectives, the aid program provides opportunities for us to advance Australia's foreign policy interests and our trade interests. We would be letting down the Australian taxpayers, who after all pay the bills for this program, if we simply ignored those opportunities.

So I make no apology for the fact that nearly 90 per cent of Australia's aid is spent on goods and services which are sourced in Australia. I make no apology to the wheat farmers of New South Wales, Victoria or South Australia for the fact that the food aid which we supply under the world food program is bought from them at a benefit to the average wheat farmer of over $800 a year. I make no apology to the rice growers of the Riverina or Leeton that our rice under the world food program is purchased from them at an average benefit per rice farmer of around $4,000. I make no apology for the fact that the steel we use in the bridges that we supply to Indonesia is made at Port Kembla or Whyalla and fabricated by workers in Seven Hills or indeed, Mr Speaker, in your own electorate.

I make no apology for the fact that the engineers who go to work on these projects are trained in Australia. I make no apology for the fact that the nurses or the teachers are Australians who are serving their country in this way and, indeed, I make no apology for the fact that the thousands of students we train in Australia are trained in institutions which are as good as, or better than, any in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Bhutan and elsewhere?

—Absolutely. I welcome the interjection from the Leader of the National Party of Australia. The fact that we spend money on Australian products does not make it bad aid, as is often implied. The fact is that by specialising in areas where we have a comparative advantage, where we are world leaders—and those areas are becoming more and more—we do advance and maximise the value of our aid while generating production and jobs back home.

PARA.TAB: The suggestion that the aid program is insufficiently focused on poverty alleviation is based on a very static, very narrow and, I believe, false definition of poverty alleviation. The fact is that sustainable economic growth is a prerequisite for economic development. It is not enough on its own, but it is essential if countries are to provide ongoing improvements in employment, health care and education—the very means of alleviating poverty. That will not happen unless there is sustainable growth. Aid simply patches up the problems and does not deal with the real issues. That is why, under our aid program, we support the construction of transport and communications facilities in Indo-China, or China, as well as village water supply systems in East Timor. It means that we build bridges in Indonesia, but we support family planning programs in the South Pacific as well. Both sorts of activities are part of any balanced aid program and will continue to be.

If we have learned anything from the last few decades it is that in the medium term the best way of improving the quality of life for people in developing countries is to give them the opportunity to help themselves. That is what we are all about. If, in the process, we can bring benefits to Australia as well, then the program is twice as useful. I thank the honourable member for Bonython for this opportunity to set at rest this calumny that is put about the aid program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, as the opportunity did not arise during the condolence motions to speak on the death of Dame Marie Breen, who was a constituent of mine, I ask your indulgence to make a brief statement at this point.
—Please proceed.

—Dame Marie Breen had a distinguished career in the Senate. As a member of my electorate, I saw her on a number of occasions, lastly when she attended the victory of the Liberal Party in Goldstein on 13 March. At her funeral service there were so many people that the crowd spilled out onto the footpath, such was the tremendous regard in which Dame Marie was held by all who knew her.

PARA.TAB: Dame Marie was asked by the Victorian Liberals to stand for parliament in 1961. She was known then for a wonderful record of community service. She was an executive member of the Victorian Baby Health Centres Association for some 36 years. From 1946 she held a number of positions in the National Council of Women, including the offices of Victorian President and National Vice-President. She played significant roles in the establishment of the Marriage Guidance Council in Victoria and the Victorian Family Council. The Family Council specifically set out to assist low income families and to provide playground facilities for children in high-rise accommodation.

The auxiliaries of the Royal Melbourne Hospital, the Southern Memorial Hospital and Hampton Rehabilitation Hospital all benefited from her work. She was mayoress of Brighton during her husband's term of office in 1941-42. Dame Marie believed that women had an important role to play in the nation's politics. She was actively involved in the Australian Women's National League from 1936. The AWNL was one of the organisations which came together to form the modern Liberal Party. She held a number of positions in the women's sections of the party, including chairman of the federal women's committee. It was due to outstanding women such as Dame Marie that the Liberal Party led the way in endorsing women for parliament. In the early 1960s, of five women in the parliament, four were Liberals.

Dame Marie was also instrumental in the establishment of the Citizens Advice Bureau, and she was a supporter of the establishment of an institute of family studies. Her outstanding record of voluntary community service had the family as its focus, and this arose out of Dame Marie's own background of a happy, stable and devoted family life. She had been raised in a close and happy family, and family and Christian values remained of overriding importance to her throughout her life. She never forgot her family, and it was to care for her husband who had been severely injured in an accident that she was later to resign from the Senate.

In 1958 Dame Marie was awarded an OBE, and in 1979 she was made a Dame of the British Empire. Within the Liberal Party she held many positions. She was state Vice-President from 1955 to 1961. Dame Marie was a wonderfully talented person with wide-ranging interests. Like Sir Edward Dunlop, she saw the very great value and importance to Australia of building our relations with Asia, and she visited many countries in the region. She was Vice-President of the Australia-Asia Association. She had a lifelong interest in music, opera and ballet. She sang with her daughter Jeanette in the Brighton philharmonic choir, and even had a season in the chorus of the National Opera.

Dame Marie embodied the finest values for which the Liberal Party stood and stands today—a belief in the pre-eminence of the family as the source of personal strength and respect for others, a strong commitment to helping others through voluntary community action, a preparedness to make personal sacrifices for the public interest and an acceptance of the importance of a strong moral basis for individual, community and political life. From her individual strength and achievement the whole of Australia benefited. I am very pleased and proud to have this opportunity to acknowledge her contribution to the House, and to give my condolences to her family.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
The Government's lack of leadership and policy to deal with unemployment and its consequences.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is budget day and the first budget in this new House was in 1988 when I sat here on the back bench and heard the Treasurer, now the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), say that this would be the budget that brought home the bacon. Perhaps this will be the budget that is characterised by the fact that the chickens have come home to roost.

PARA.TAB: In recent months we have had numerous indications from this government of how bereft it is in developing strategies to deal with the chronic problem of unemployment in Australia. We have had the Prime Minister previously and today talking about novel approaches to try to deal with long-term unemployment. Yesterday we had the extraordinary feat of the minister at the table, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley), in a speech entitled `Unemployment: Dimensions and Challenges' made at the ANU, saying that long-term unemployed people had as much hope of finding the Loch Ness monster as they did at scoring a job. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . you could only get 750 to 1 on the immediate discovery of the Loch Ness Monster.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you had better read the speech rather than the press reports.

—I have it here; I will read it in a moment. The minister and his government have effectively given up on unemployment. They have thrown their hands up in the air and said, `We haven't got a clue'. It is interesting to contrast that with some of the comments that were made before the election. On 12 February the Prime Minister, on a radio program in Queensland, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . unemployment probably has peaked and may be now coming off, coming down.
Two days later in the first great debate he said:
We're seeing now job growth coming through. I think we're on the cusp of a significant recovery.
I am confident it's (unemployment) peaked and it's on its way down.

That contrasts interestingly with his comments to his staff, not meant for publication, the night before the election when he boasted that unemployment had been neutralised as an election issue. I am sure the 924,000 Australians who are unemployed will be pleased to know that they have been neutralised and that the Prime Minister has the attitude that if he can get them off the agenda they do not matter. But there was every reason to think that they had to be addressed. Even the government's own adviser Bruce Chapman from the ANU, over 12 months ago, in a report that he wrote, said:

The current state of the Australian labour market augurs poorly for those already disadvantaged in the labour force, of which there are, and continue to be, very many. Our estimates and projections imply strongly the number of long term unemployed will be, by a large margin, at unprecedented and still growing levels over the next two years. There is not, now, any chance of avoiding this.

A significant aspect of that is that there is not now any chance of avoiding it, but there was, and always was, if there had been some action and not merely rhetoric. At the end of June at the National Press Club the minister made a speech in which he candidly and honestly addressed the problems of unemployment. It is a pity that same candour and honesty could not have been shown before the election. There were comments such as:
Our goal is to reduce unemployment as far as we can during the period of economic growth. To do so we should take every step, no matter how small, which can have a net positive impact on jobs.
Those sorts of comments are right through the speech. Another comment was:
We should not despair at the magnitude of the task. Every tenth of a percentage point off the unemployment rate is another 9,000 people, real people, with real families, back in work—
unless, of course, the participation rate is jumping around. He said:
No level of unemployment that we are likely to see in the near future could be regarded as satisfactory.

Our commitment, as a government and as a nation, should not be to any arbitrary unemployment number or rate. Our commitment must be to the reduction of unemployment as rapidly and as completely as possible.

The trouble with all of this is that it is just rhetoric; there is no substance. Who has been here for 10 years? Who has been around and running the place? All of a sudden it is though it is a problem we have only now discovered. The Prime Minister has got in on the act. At his Evatt Foundation lecture he made similar bleating noises about unemployment. He said:

The principal aim of this government will be to reduce the number of unemployed Australians. And so long as there is a pool of unemployed, of whatever dimension, the aim must be to decrease the amount of time people are spending in it.
Fine. He went on to say:
We will need from all the players in the employment equation recognition of our profound responsibility, not only to the unemployed and those facing unemployment, but to Australia as a whole.

Where is the policy to go with the rhetoric? It simply does not exist. It is simply all talk. It is simply part of a strategy to neutralise unemployment for another two years. The Prime Minister's best comment in that speech came late in it when he said:
Tonight I have said very little about the economic future. I could quote you the evidence, the unmistakable evidence of the sea-change which has occurred in Australia.

That is the vision of the Prime Minister, but his vision is very narrow. His vision does not extend to the people who have been displaced by his 10 years as Treasurer or Prime Minister. His vision is very myopic. His vision could use glasses, but he had better get them today because he will not be able to get a rebate for them after tonight.

PARA.TAB: His vision does not include people such as Norma who were talked about in the Salvation Army annual report that came out a little while ago. Norma is a long-time unemployed person. This is how the Salvation Army describes her in its annual report to try to put a face to the 924,000 people unemployed or the over 350,000 long-term unemployed:

SPEECH.PARA: Norma Banks is a warm, gregarious 50 year old, who lives by herself in a privately rented flat in an inner Melbourne suburb. Twelve months ago she was retrenched from a large printing company: she had worked for them for 21 years.

They came along last October 12 months. We knew there were cuts going on. And they offered a voluntary redundancy package to 147 over the age of 47. We could see what was going to happen if you didn't fit into the restructure. We could see they would turn around and say "we don't need you, you're gone". So I got out before I was demoralised and told "right, you're out the door".
I loved my job. I loved the people, I'm a people person. It was a family. It was life. I thought I was secure, had a job for life. And then "bang" you're out of it. You're out of the contact.
In the first months after her retrenchment Norma decided not to immediately look for another job. "I gave myself a bit of a break. It was an unwinding period. I gave myself a bit of space".

PARA.TAB: But in the last nine months she has been actively looking for work—regularly visiting the CES and checking newspaper advertisements. Not only has Norma found a scarcity of work, "You go into the CES and there's not a job you could do on the board", she has also found that employers are loath to employ older workers.

SPEECH.PARA: You get to phone basis and they ask how old you are and you say 50 and they say we really need someone a bit younger. They think 50 plus is over the hill.

That is part of the social dimension of what unemployment and long-term unemployment is doing to Australia. It is well known to people who sit over that side. In 1980, the Prime Minister, then a shadow minister, made this statement in the House of Representatives:

The Government will not tell us where it will supply some jobs in the cities of Australia. This is a very urbanised country and the Government does not have a policy for providing employment where it matters. If honourable members opposite think that the Baader-Meinhof groups and the urban guerrillas in western Europe will not be a feature of Australia as we move through the 1980s with high levels of unemployment in the cities, I think they may be disappointed.

Today we have Mr Baader-Meinhof occupying the Prime Minister's chair. The social dimension of the problem he has created is worth repeating. Today almost 700,000 Australian kids are growing up in homes where no parent has a job. Almost one in five children aged 14 and under live in homes where no parent has a job. Almost 300,000 kids are living in homes where the family breadwinner is unemployed. One in nine Australian workers are unemployed.

PARA.TAB: Bishop Challen from the Brotherhood of St Laurence has warned that we face a real risk of workers over 40 years of age never again being able to find work. This parliament's Senate issued a report stating:

SPEECH.PARA: There is a real possibility that many of the young people now unemployed will never work. Many of them will be the second generation in their families cut off from the benefits bestowed by full-time jobs.

In its medium term review of the economy, EPAC recently forecast single income families as falling behind dual income families and likely to lag further through this decade. That is what is happening with income distribution in Australia. The fact is that Australia is a much more unfair and uneven society today than it was 10 years ago at the end of the last recession. This was put very well by Max Walsh who recently wrote in the Age:

Despite the well-known expression "the rich get richer and the poor get poorer", life for most of the last 40 odd years hasn't worked that way in Australia. The fruits of growth, especially as measured in terms of the wages, were for the most part skewed favourably towards the lower-income groups. However under a Labor Government, this egalitarian trend has gone into reverse. For Australian wage-earners over the past decade, the rich have got richer and the poor, poorer.

The figures Max was talking about relate to the fact that 10 years ago the top one per cent of wealth was owned by the same number of people who made up the bottom 10 per cent of the Australian population. Today, one per cent of the population owns as much as the bottom 23 per cent. He commented on that as follows:

I suspect that most members of our Labor Government will be rather shocked to find that under their administration the gap between the lower and higher-paid people in our society has not only widened but that the poorest have gone backwards.

That cannot be explained by the recession. That is comparing us with the end of the last recession. The Salvation Army annual report makes chilling reading. Last year a record 1 1/2 million in a country of 17 million people sought help from the Salvos. It was predicted that 40,000 single adults and families would be homeless in the next 12 months because of unemployment. The report said that cash and food vouchers were often fully used within the first two hours of opening in Melbourne each day and that there were alarming levels of sexual abuse and domestic violence. These were the biggest causes of the increase in youth homelessness. One of the strongest conclusions of the report was:

While economic restructuring might offer stimulating challenges to governments and the business community, it has been a crippling experience for displaced workers, their families and communities. It results in diminished control over our lives and is causing a political backlash as resentment increases.
So what is the response? The response is simply all talk. The minister interjected earlier and suggested that I read his speech. I will read out some parts of it. Towards the end, he stated:
So far I have talked about policies to encourage growth and remove barriers in the labour market . . .
He also stated:
We need to look critically . . . at the non-economic restrictions on business.

He said we need to look critically at on-costs and regulations. He said, `We need, we need'. Of course we need! What we really need is some action. We need to stop talking and actually do something in this country. At another point in his speech was his rhetoric about solving unemployment—but again it is just rhetoric. We come back to the need for strategies that maximise stable and sustainable economic and employment growth and that act directly to reduce the numbers of the long-term unemployed. That is fine, but where has he been for 10 years? Where was he 12 months ago when Bruce Chapman was saying there was a problem?

PARA.TAB: In his speech, he also commented that these lessons point to two overall policy priorities—to `maximise stable and sustainable economic growth' and to `act directly to reduce the numbers of long-term unemployed'. They are fine sentiments; but how do we do it? He can keep talking about it for only so long. The response of the government so far has been twofold: talk, talk, talk; and, when talk runs a bit thin, report, reports, reports.

A report is coming back to us in July next year. The government's republican advisory committee can advise in a matter of months; the committee to advise on unemployment takes 13 or 14 months. That is far better timing for an election than a short-term republican committee. In the end, in the words of the minister, `Where to from here?'. It is fairly simple: face up to the responsibilities, stop talking, do something and actually offer some hope.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Dr Wooldridge) that he chooses effectively to debate this very important issue in such undergraduate terms. Part of the problem of an undergraduate debating society in this area is that it is almost invariably part of the characteristic of those who take a particular side in an undergraduate debate that they are unaware of the implications of their overall policy stances; and often how inappropriate it is, given those policy stances, that they cite the facts that they do to support their argument.

PARA.TAB: Nothing could have been more evident in the remarks of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition than that. He introduced a report lamenting what he said was a suppression, a lowering, of incomes of low paid workers. The entirety of opposition wages policy has been directed towards lowering that further. In so far as the opposition has any labour market policies at all, in getting people back into the work force, it would have people who are unemployed directly replacing low paid workers with people operating with a 25 per cent reduction.

He goes on to quote from a report by the Salvation Army, lamenting rightly that there are substantial casualties of economic restructuring. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) says repeatedly in public forums, `The government's economic restructuring is too slow'. He cites that as an argument that ought to be made for his position against the government. He demands that the government, which is required to give serious detailed thought to the problems which confront it, comes forward with solutions, as he termed it, yet when opposition members themselves have been questioned, albeit in the run-up to an election when one would have thought they might have tried to come up with at least a few answers, they have come forward with nothing. His leader, just before Christmas last year, was asked:

SPEECH.PARA: At what point in your first term do you think you will start to make inroads into the unemployment rate?
The Leader of the Opposition said:
I don't know where we will be. I will be happy to give you the predictions when we get there .
So there is not any noticeable improvement in the first 12 months. The interviewer said:
Are you prepared to countenance that you might actually see a rise in the unemployment rate in the first 12 months?
The Leader of the Opposition replied:
Well, I mean I'm happy to tell you that when I know.

He gives the government no latitude to sit down and seriously think through an issue with substantial long-term implications. About his education policies, which presumably also include his labour market policies, he said:
The federal opposition would retain its existing policy on education until a wide ranging review could take place.

No date was put on for that operation. The fact is that the federal government has a response. That response is to go right to the heart of the problems that will emerge in the area of unemployment. We have to face certain facts about it. I think we are at a stage of the election cycle when we can probably have a sensible debate and discussion between us on unemployment; so I will stop making the same undergraduate points about the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that he managed to make for 15 minutes about me since there are serious matters here for both sides of this House to deliberate on if we are to stop the sorts of social costs that he talked about and that I have talked about in the two speeches I have made. By the way, in those speeches I did not at any point say that the long-term unemployed had a better chance of seeing Nessie than of getting a job. There is absolutely no juxtaposition of those two propositions in the course of my remarks, although some journalist seems to have seen his way clear to finding that.

PARA.TAB: We have to start to take a look—not just start because we have been taking a look at it for some time and doing something about it—at the central problem in the nature of the economy, which is not unique to Australia but a phenomenon being experienced by the entire OECD at the moment. In each recession that we have had over the last 20 years the level of long-term unemployment has plateaued higher and higher. After each recession larger and larger numbers of Australians, Britons, Americans, Canadians and Europeans have found themselves unemployed and in the position where they will never get back into the work force.

We could have had two or three times the average job growth of the OECD over the previous 10 years with 1.6 million new jobs in this country but we would have found a reduction in the unemployment numbers through that 10 years heyday of only some 300,000. In other words, of those 1.6 million jobs, 1.3 million were new people joining the work force. Even on the most optimistic predictions for the next seven or eight years, something like that phenomenon will occur again. There will be a very substantial number of people finding work, but they will be new entrants to the work force, newly trained people, who had previously not considered entering the work force and had now decided to do so. The long-term unemployed will find themselves increasingly uncompetitive.

Most people enter the work force through a personal network. People every day, even in the depth of a recession, find new jobs and change jobs, not in simply ones and twos but in hundreds and thousands. Enormous changes are going on in the work force all the time. The vast bulk of people are finding those working opportunities basically through the networks that they have established personally—for example, they know somebody who has a job on offer.

But for those who do not make it, for those whose networks fall down, as time goes by their employability dramatically reduces to the point where, unless they are being serviced by either an active program from the CES or a labour market program associated with it, they will not get a job at all. One of the problems the honourable member for Chisholm needs to think about as he sits down and contemplates his own policies, because he has an obligation to develop his party policy, is this: the Liberal Party went into the last election campaign with proposals for dramatic cuts in labour market spending. And I saw some totally ignorant remarks of its finance spokesman today, urging further cuts in our labour market programs on the rumour that there may be additional expenditure in that area. He needs to understand this and he needs to get it into his skull and particularly into his heart: if someone does not get access to one of these programs, if he or she is a long-term unemployed person, he or she will not get into the work force.

It is not a question that that person might not get into the work force; that person will not get into the work force. Basically, all the people who are long-term unemployed who found work over the last couple of years had been through some part of those labour market programs or had been through the CES as a product of their activity.

Let me take it a point further: we are the object of criticism in the media because our comparative expenditures on labour market programs compared to an OECD average as a percentage of GDP is much lower than the OECD average. That is basically correct. Not as correct as those statistics would indicate because they are taken at a point a little too early, and our spending on labour market programs has more than doubled in the last couple of years, and they took it at a point early.

But even with that doubling, that still is a correct point. It is not a correct point in the percentage of unemployed served by labour market programs—percentages of unemployed served in Australia in comparison to the rest in the OECD are about the same. But our labour market programs on the whole tend to be very much cheaper than the programs that exist in the OECD, and those programs in the OECD are very expensive ones indeed. So we do serve as many unemployed people as does the OECD but not with the same level of generosity.

However, I want to make another point to the Liberal Party members about this and to get it into their skulls, hearts and minds: they are now, outside the United States, the only conservative party in the world which opposes labour market programs and the associated training arrangements. It was a pleasure for me to go to the United Kingdom and at least see operating on the European social fund a conservative party making an attempt to make those programs within their own light, to make sense in a way that was acceptable to them in the framework of their own ideology. And one or two of their programs were working very well indeed. I am interested in them, and we will have a look at those successful programs for implementation over here.

But the fact of the matter is that it is the British tories, the Thatcherites, who are operating extensive labour market programs, which the Liberal Party wishes to cut in order to provide what it called its particular tax breaks in the course of the last election campaign—policy which the Liberal Party has not revised. This is its position.

There is now a great deal of literature, a great deal of understanding about the utter significance of this in transforming the lives of people who have become disconnected from the work force. It is getting the right mix of those which will be absolutely essential to getting people back to work. Those sorts of levels of unemployment that we have been discussing, that the honourable member for Chisholm has mentioned and that I have mentioned both today and in those couple of speeches, will not be resolved simply by the ordinary workings of the labour market in an economic recovery.

There is amongst the conservatives now almost a meeting of mind with the radicals, the most bleeding hearts and the economic rationalists, who get together amongst those who know what policies it is that they are handling. And those do not conceivably include the conservatives on the opposition benches because the conservatives know how inefficient it is for a labour market in the unemployed sector not to be competitive with those in the work force. But we can get the phenomena.

I saw anecdotal evidence of it in Britain when I was there a couple of weeks ago because in one of the newspapers it appeared at the same time. With an unemployment level in practical terms much heavier than ours and a regional unemployment level much more atrocious than the sorts of regional problems that we confront in Australia, an employer was in the process of laying off people but was talking about the annual wage rise for British workers. He said, `It is tough here. People are being laid off. There are very difficult circumstances. We can only afford a wage rise of 5 per cent'—a wage rise of 5 per cent in the midst of that situation which he was confronting.

When I was in the United Kingdom the time previously, the railway workers had successfully secured for themselves an 11 per cent rise a year or two previously in the sort of atmosphere in which they operated. Because the fact of the matter was, and the fact of the matter is now, that one can have massive areas of unemployment, regions of unemployment, but it has no impact in exercising any set of discipline on wage levels and inflation rates in the economy as a whole simply because those workers are no longer capable of entering any competitive arrangements.

If the Liberal Party is worried about the positions of middle-aged men—those who are regarded as too old for a job—it has to go straight to the heart of these things and understand that these problems are not solved by people sitting around on their butts talking about changes in the structure of the work force helping the unemployed. Changes in the structure of the work force do not mean a damn to them.

The Liberal Party will not solve these problems by sitting around saying, `If we get massive growth rates that alone will achieve the objective'. If one does not get growth rates, of course one will not get unemployment coming down. But having got unemployment coming down, basically all one will address is those areas of the labour market which most readily churn, that is, those in employment or those newly trained. There will be absolutely no chance that people will find themselves in a situation where they will get into work.

Contemplate the fact that, unless a person is in one of our labour market programs, he or she has absolutely no chance of success, and then look at what those programs achieve because I think we have a more and varied labour market program than most. On the latest figures available to me, of those who found themselves in unsubsidised work or training after three months of receiving one of our programs, of those in Jobstart, 60 per cent were still effectively in work; Jobtrain, 38 per cent; special intervention program, 42 per cent; Job Search training, 43 per cent; mobility assistance scheme, 81 per cent; accredited training for youth, 44 per cent; Skillshare, 42 per cent; Jobskills, 44 per cent; and the other smaller labour market programs, 40 per cent—total, 45.6 per cent.

It would be great if it were 100 per cent; there is no question about that. But at the moment, for those who are not in those programs, it is 100 per cent failure. So these labour market programs are getting people at their point of need—these programs which the Liberal Party's finance spokesman dismisses this morning, without alternatives, as something that ought not to be an opportunity given to our work force who find themselves unemployed. Before he rocks into this place again he should do a bit of thinking. It ain't no good producing comments from the Salvation Army or from the Anglican welfare organisations or from anyone else whose comments are a condemnation of the direction of the Liberal Party's whole unamended program and using that as a point of criticism on us.

Opposition members should not come into this place saying that we are doing nothing, when at the same time their spokesman is attacking us for doing the very things that are so successful and which I have referred to. They should come up with a few alternatives. I am prepared to listen to the British tories on one or two alternatives, so in principle I ought to at least be prepared to listen to them. But they had better have a few alternatives because they have not shown us a darn thing yet in any of the propositions they have put forward. So they should not go around the country trying to exploit this issue. It is three years off an election anyway; it will not do them any good. They should come in here with a few solutions and work with us because we are trying to work it out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I should like to apologise to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) because I am not even an undergraduate. So I hope that he listens to what I have to say because what I am going to say affects a lot of people in my electorate, as I am sure it affects a lot of people throughout Australia—and I was really sorry to hear the demeaning remark he made to the previous speaker.

PARA.TAB: On the Friday before the last federal election, I was campaigning in my electorate. I walked into a business house and there were three gentlemen standing there having a talk. I walked up and shook hands with them and two of them walked away. I said to the one man who was left there, `You must be the proprietor of this business. How is it going?'. He said, `I'll tell you how it is going. I just sacked these two gentlemen who were talking to me. If you blokes don't get in tomorrow, I will be sacking a few more. Depending on how things go and whoever is in government, I will have to make up my mind whether I close the business down or not because there is no way we can continue under this regime. It is just impossible to continue on'.

As I saw the numbers coming up on the night of the election I could not believe them—and I still do not believe them, but I am afraid I have to accept them. The first person I thought of was that gentleman who told me that he had not slept the night before and that his stomach was in a knot at having to sack these workers. I suppose they were men of about 45 to 50 years of age. They had no opportunity of getting another job. Today I still feel guilty about those people who are out of work.

In this House we are not permitted to call people liars or talk about a lying campaign, but the last election campaign by the government was a con and a fraud on the people of Australia. Millions of dollars were spent in trying to destroy the opposition's campaign. Our campaign was effectively destroyed by the government telling untruths. We thought we had the answer to a number of Australia's problems. We were going to do something. We said to the people, `This is what we are going to try to do. In some areas it might cause a little pain, but we want to do something for our children and our grandchildren down the line'. Unfortunately, the people of Australia rejected that.

Tonight we will see exactly what is going on with this country. The budget will certainly contain some goodies, but what is given with one hand will be more than taken with the other. That is not going to help our job prospects.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training mentioned all the different government programs under a number of acronyms. People come to my office every day and say, `I am on this program', `I am on that program', or some other program. I congratulate the people who find work through those programs, and the businesses that succeed despite the government. But if the government were doing something to reconstruct the whole system, people could get jobs. The government would not need the socialist approach of using taxpayer's money to try to find work for the unemployed.

The private sector creates the only real jobs in Australia. During the election campaign I spoke to the operators of businesses and the story was the same everywhere I went, `Look, Noel, we are getting older. We are working harder than we have ever worked in our lives. We would like to sell our business or let our children take it over. But, of course, we can't. The business is our superannuation. We cannot sell it because of the recession. The only way we are going to get out of this business is in a pine box'. That is a terrible attitude, but that is the way things are going in this country today.

How can the government help? It says, `We have all these wonderful programs'. The government can put a bandaid on the problem to try to help the situation, but we still have the additional costs and burdens of the superannuation guarantee levy, the fringe benefits tax, payroll tax—for which we said we would compensate the state governments—and the fuel levy. Until these are removed businesses are not going to employ anyone.

There is a rumour going around town that the government is going to put a tax on leaded fuel. The claim is that it is to help the environment, but we all know that its purpose is to increase government revenue. When this government says that it is trying to assist the situation, why does it always impose a penalty, instead of giving people incentives? Business people and workers want incentives. They do not want to be told they cannot do something, otherwise they will be punished. The government should have realised this by now.

A fuel levy will greatly affect my electorate of Riverina because everything is trucked in and everything is trucked out. Young people going to school will be affected. The people who will have to pay for the fuel levy will be those who can least afford it. Why does the government not do something about macro-economic reform and micro-economic reform? Why does it not do something about the car industry so that people do not have to drive around Australia in cars which are 10 to 12 years old and which do not have all these pollution corrections on them? Let us boost the car industry so that people can afford these cars.

I represent a rural electorate where unemployment continues to bump along—it is getting worse as the days go by—despite the fact that Riverina is one of the wealthiest producing electorates in Australia. Commodity prices are down. Government costs and charges continue to rise. One has only to look at inspection charges. One of my constituents is an exporter. It costs him $86 for a half-hour inspection of one container. How can we compete with overseas countries with charges like that? If he has to catch a ship on the weekend, it costs $308 an hour to inspect a container. Is this madness, or is it madness? This is crazy business.

We talk about these labour creation programs with their various acronyms, instead of doing something about the real problems that face Australia. Our geographical situation and our competitiveness demand that we have to be a lean and mean machine. To do that we have to be not only as good as, but better than other nations. We talk about the OECD, but we have to do it ourselves.

Unemployment is having a dramatic effect on the community. Young people cannot find work. If young people cannot find work they get into the habit of not getting up and of being lethargic. What happens then? They are in the system. I feel so sorry for those young people. I feel even more sorry for the older people. People of about my age, or younger, have their youngsters going to school and they have all those additional costs. They can no longer afford to send their children to the school of their choice. They find themselves almost on the scrap heap. They feel that no-one wants them and that they are no use to anyone. There are other associated problems.

The middle class—if we can call it that—is disappearing. As other speakers have said, the rich are getting richer and the poor are getting poorer. The people on whom the whole basis of Australian society was constructed are disappearing. They are no longer there. More and more people are unemployed, and fewer and fewer people are looking after them.

It is bad enough for the unemployed, but what is happening to families? A lady in my electorate has a single income family receiving $404 a week. She wrote to me and listed all her costs and charges. There is no way that that family can survive. What are they going to do? There are two solutions. The family has to break up and the mother has to become a single supporting mother, or the father has to go on the dole and the teenager has to go on one of these social security programs where a flat is provided at the expense of the taxpayer. That is a terrible situation.

I hope tonight's budget imposes no additional taxes on the citrus or the wine industries. The wine industry is an Australian success story, but it appears that the government does not really like success stories; it likes to slow them down and give them some hurdles to jump over and make it tough for them so that they too can put people out of work. The citrus industry is already going through a trauma. The government should be ashamed if there is a tax on the citrus industry. Recently we were going to have a protest rally in front of Parliament House, but the situation is so bad in Australia today that the farmers cannot even afford to get down here for a protest rally. It is diabolical.

Recently the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said that there is some confusion in society. I listened to the Prime Minister's confused speech on Mabo. If anyone could make anything out of that, I will go he. If the Prime Minister is as confused about looking after the economy and providing jobs for people as he is about Mabo, then I am afraid we are in for a real tough time ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, it is my task to rise today to oppose this matter of public importance introduced by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Dr Wooldridge). It is absolutely amazing that the opposition can come into this House and lambast the government for a lack of policy in this area. The government has a very clear policy and a very clear commitment: to generate jobs and to do something substantial about unemployment in the long term.

PARA.TAB: That is not the case with the opposition. What have we had from the opposition in recent times since the election? Its only priorities are: who is going to be the leader of the Liberal Party, and who is going to be the President of the Liberal Party. It is not talking about ideas in the way that this government is talking about ideas. It is not talking about the ideas that the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) was talking about, and it has not been talking about the ideas that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been talking about.

This government has a very serious approach in place, and that is the white paper on employment. That white paper on employment will be every bit as significant as the Chifley white paper on employment in 1945. It will bring forward a new approach to this problem, and it will build on the achievements of this government during its 10 years in power.

What do we hear from the Liberal Party and the National Party? We hear about Hewson, we hear about Reith, we hear about Howard, we hear about Goldsworthy—we hear about all the personalities fighting. Who cares who is President of the Liberal Party? The unemployed do not care who is President of the Liberal Party and, frankly, they do not care who is leader of the Liberal Party either because neither of them is talking about the ideas that are so important to the future of this country. Fair dinkum, we might as well have Marcel Marceau on the other side of the House because there is nothing emerging—no ideas are emerging from the opposition.

Members of the opposition come in here and talk about the social problems of unemployment. We share those concerns, and that is why we have commissioned the white paper on employment. That is why the minister for employment has been giving the speeches he has given. That is why the Prime Minister is doing the same thing. But what do we get from the Liberal Party? Let us look at some honest assessments of the policy approach and ideas of the Liberal Party. Let us look at what Chris Puplick had to say about the Liberal Party. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal Party is a dangerously narrow church.

He also said that `entry to the party had to stop being a test of ideological purity and should only be a question of talent and merit'. What did Malcolm Fraser have to say about ideas in the Liberal Party? Only recently, on 9 July, the Canberra Times reported:

Malcolm Fraser last night launched a blistering attack on the economic rationalism of the Liberal Party before members of the Australian Liberal Students Federation in Melbourne. Mr Fraser said its proponents had marginalised the Liberal Party with `stupid and mad ideas'.

The ideas that remain in the Liberal and National parties are indeed that. If we look at Fightback and what it had to say about unemployment, they are indeed stupid and mad ideas—dangerous ideas—because what the opposition proposed in Fightback, what it has not repudiated here today or at any stage since the election, is its approach of massive cuts to public expenditure, massive cuts to labour market programs, abolition of the CES, abolition of the award system, and hourly rates of pay of $3 for young people. That is the opposition's solution to this problem, and that has not been repudiated.

PARA.TAB: The most important thing, as the minister for employment said in this House a short time ago, is that even in Thatcher's Britain that way of thinking has now been repudiated. Even the Conservatives in Great Britain now realise that governments have to intervene. They have to intervene through bodies such as the CES, which the opposition proposes to abolish. They have to intervene through labour market programs, which were earlier rubbished by a member of the National Party.In Fightback, the opposition proposed to cut expenditure on labour market programs by something like $400 million to $500 million. As the minister for employment said earlier, for the long-term unemployed there is no alternative to those labour market programs. The CES is their only friend. What did the opposition put in Fightback that it has not repudiated? The opposition still proposes to abolish the CES.

If the opposition wants a serious debate about the future of employment in this country, it should come up with some ideas. It should look at the sort of thinking that is going on overseas and support the government in this white paper process. It should get involved for the future of this country. It should help us produce a white paper which can radically change our approach to these issues because they are not the same issues they were a decade ago.

The problem with the opposition is that it has not changed its thinking. There are no ideas. I refer the opposition to what is being said overseas on this question. I might remind honourable members opposite that there are plenty of OECD reports in this area. For example, I will shortly quote from a recent English textbook which now acknowledges that unemployment is of itself an impediment to economic recovery. That is why governments must intervene and spend money on labour market programs if they hope to do something about the problem in the long term.

This government does not pretend, and did not pretend during the election campaign, that there was any magic wand that we could wave. We acknowledge that the only path for this country to take is to make ourselves more internationally competitive, to export more and to generate jobs in the private sector. The fact of the matter is—the opposition is ignorant of this fact—that even if we get substantial growth going for the rest of this century, we will still be left with a significant number of long-term unemployed. That is what honourable members opposite fail to acknowledge. A recent English text on unemployment states:

SPEECH.PARA: Unemployment is a major source of human misery. Despite economic growth it is a bigger problem now in the last 50 years. In western Europe three times more people are out of work than in the 1960s and the numbers in eastern Europe are rising rapidly.
. . . it has become more and more obvious that the average level itself varies greatly between decades, with previous unemployment exerting a persistent effect on subsequent unemployment.

Governments throughout western Europe have recognised that fact. That is why they have committed themselves to creating active labour market programs, to stimulating the economy through budget deficits, and to intervening in the market through bodies such as the Commonwealth Employment Service in order to assist the innocent victims of structural and technological change. What we now have is a fundamental, structural change in our work force with rising participation rates, which means that growth cannot cater for all those who want to work.

PARA.TAB: We on this side of the House say that it must remain our aim to provide work for all of those who wish to work. When we cannot do it because of the ongoing effect of the recession and when we cannot do it because of rapid technological and structural change, then we as a government and a community have a responsibility to intervene. It is precisely that responsibility which is recognised in the United States of America and Britain, but there is only one group left in the western world that does not recognise it—the Liberal-National parties in Australia. They are bereft of ideas in that area.

I invite their members to come with us on an adventure, to think for a change and to get involved with the white paper process. I invite them to come along and participate, to work with their communities, because the community now understands that this is a long-term problem which requires long-term solutions and new approaches. The government says that openly; it does not seek to hide it. We say that openly, but the opposition pretends that nothing has changed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Except during election campaigns.

—During the election campaign we acknowledged that there were no magic wands—no magic wands at all. All that members of the opposition can do is sit around and grizzle and whinge about why they lost the election. The reason they lost the election is that, fundamentally, they were out of touch with the Australian people. The Australian people want their politicians to recognise that there are problems in the community and to talk to them about long-term solutions. The opposition showed during the election campaign that its solutions were caught in a time warp and that is why it was rejected.

PARA.TAB: The public is intelligent enough to understand that these problems will not be solved by laissez-faire economic approaches to these issues. The public is intelligent enough to know that a time of high level of unemployment is not the time to go around slapping on a huge GST, slashing the deficit, abolishing the CES, knocking people off unemployment benefits after six months, or all of the other mad things that the opposition proposed during the campaign and which Malcolm Fraser acknowledged only a few months ago.
