TALK.START.PARA: —The Murray-Darling Basin Bill enters this House for the third time. Let us hope that this time it is successful and the debate is concluded. It is an extremely important bill dealing with an extremely important region of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The bill gives effect to a revised Murray-Darling Basin agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia for the improved management of the land, water and environmental resources of the Murray-Darling Basin. As of July 1992, the agreement has been operating in principle pending passage of this legislation; so it has certainly been travelling for the last 12 months and one month in principle.

The revised agreement incorporates a salinity and drainage strategy which addresses the dual problems of the River Murray—salinity and waterlogging—and land salination in the upper Murray. The amended agreement provides for water allocation through a system of continuous water accounting. This will allow New South Wales and Victoria to draw on their annual water allocation according to need. Unused allocations will be carried forward as credits. Above allocation drawings will be carried forward as debits against future entitlements. It is believed that this will facilitate the optimal use of a shared resource without disruption of fundamental access guarantees.

The bill gives the commission more financial flexibility by allowing the commission, with council approval, to carry over limited funds from one year to the next. Finally—and this is of particular interest to me—following the successful passage of this bill the first schedule to be brought forward for approval will be one authorising the assent of Queensland to the agreement. Practically the entire area that is affected by this bill lies within my electorate of Maranoa; in fact, only the city of Toowoomba, which is in the electorate of Groom, lies outside the electorate of Maranoa. So the passage of this bill is of particular interest to me.

Almost 25 per cent of the basin lies in Queensland, including the headwaters of the Darling River, which is a major tributary of the Murray River. Also at issue is the election pledge—I am not quite sure whether it was a pledge or a promise—of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to proceed with the nomination of Lake Eyre for world heritage listing. The consequences such a listing may have on the Lake Eyre and Murray-Darling basins cannot be ignored.

The Murray-Darling Basin covers more than a million square kilometres—virtually all of inland south-eastern Australia—and approximately one-seventh of the continent. The river system is among the longest in the world, draining a region 1,450 kilometres long and 1,000 kilometres wide. Three-quarters of New South Wales is located in the vicinity of the basin—well over half of Victoria, 15 per cent of Queensland and seven per cent of South Australia. The basin also includes the whole of the Australian Capital Territory, Canberra being its largest centre of population. Altogether, nearly two million people live within the basin catchment and a large number of people outside the catchment region are supported by its resources.

The annual value of the basin's primary and secondary production is about $10 billion, which accounts for between 30 and 40 per cent of the total production from Australia's natural resource based industries. So the basin is of immense importance as an employer and a creator of wealth which all of us in Australia share. Half of Australia's crop land, half the sheep flock, and 25 per cent of beef and dairy cattle are within the basin region, so the basin is far more than simply a food basket. I put it to the House that it is critical for the future of Australian agriculture and for so many jobs that are created as a result of the wealth that it creates.

Some 140 parks have been established throughout the basin to conserve areas of natural habitat and landscapes. The area is littered with culturally and historically significant sites. Adjacent to the Murray-Darling Basin lies the Lake Eyre basin catchment region, another region of the great Australian inland river systems. The Lake Eyre basin is one of the world's largest internally draining wetland systems. The area represents 16 per cent of the Australian land mass, which equates to about 1.25 million square kilometres. The federal government's proposal to nominate the basin area for world heritage listing is really quite laughable. However, let us move back to the Murray River.

The Murray River in its natural state suffers severe variability of flow, as is typical of many Australian rivers. It obviously reflects the unpredictable nature of seasons and the weather patterns throughout the continent. Given this factor, the River Murray waters agreement was entered into in 1915. This agreement was largely aimed at improving river flows for navigation and irrigation purposes. In the early settlement and development of inland Australia, the Murray River system and the Darling River system were major transport routes for much of the produce of that region.

Engineering solutions to problems of water management dominated the River Murray waters agreement and the subsequent River Murray Commission. In late 1987 the agreement was changed to become the Murray-Darling Basin agreement, reflecting greater community interest in the preservation and management of the basin's vital and irreplaceable resource. The Murray-Darling Basin agreement established a ministerial council consisting of up to three ministers from each government who have prime responsibility for matters relating to water, land and the environment. The aim of the agreement was to initiate a more cooperative approach to basin-wide resource and environment management than would be possible through independent action by the Commonwealth and states. The agreement recognises that state boundaries should not hinder responsible water management. The same principle applies to the Lake Eyre world heritage nomination. The ecological realities of the situation transcend state boundaries. I am sure the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) would be well aware of that fact.

The Queensland Minister for Environment and Heritage, Molly Robson, has naively stated that the push by the South Australian conservation movement to nominate parts of the Lake Eyre basin for world heritage listing does not impact on Queensland. She would know however, but conveniently has not made the point, that the Commonwealth has the power to override any opposition from the states.

The proposed world heritage region in the Lake Eyre basin is larger than any listed heritage area in the world. It is larger than the world heritage regions of the Great Barrier Reef, the Tasmanian wilderness, Kakadu and the Rocky Mountains combined. The implications for submitting a management plan for an area of this size are overwhelming. This country represents some of the most remote and inaccessible regions in Australia. It is unfortunate that regulation has displaced convention in the management of our unique environment. Is world heritage classification to be the only criterion for our unique landmarks and precious resources? The Lake Eyre region is already heavily protected under the National Estate and the relevant national parks acts. Any proposal to extend preservation measures should also take into consideration the preservation of our economic opportunities.

That was never more evident than in a recent visit I made to Mount Isa in the electorate of Kennedy where I had discussions with the MIM mining company which gave us an insight into exploration and the mines that it will be opening up in the very near future which lie within the Lake Eyre basin catchment area.

The major proportion of Australia's mineral resources—including copper, gas, gold, oil, lead and zinc—is located within the limits of the Lake Eyre catchment basin. Wool and beef are the principal commodities produced in the Queensland region of the basin. The value of production attributed to western Queensland shires located in the Lake Eyre catchment totalled a massive $241 million in 1991. That point was made very clear to us in my recent visit to the Diamantina Shire Council's headquarters at Bedourie which is on the Eyre Creek and Georgina River which ultimately flows down to Lake Eyre. That $241 million represents a massive 62 per cent of the region's entire output. A large proportion of the remaining output is attributed to sectors servicing grazing districts. The Lake Eyre basin is a good example of a well-managed and productive natural resource.

Too often, under international treaties and Commonwealth legislation, outside expertise dictates the evolution of our natural environment. It is about time that this government stood up for Australians and their way of life. Instead, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) recently announced the formation of a task force to `undertake a joint survey of the environmental values of the Lake Eyre basin'. The task force will consist of federal and state officers with experience and expertise in arid zone ecology and management, as well as other experts as required.

The minister is confident of developing a strategy to provide protection while allowing the sustainable use of the region's resources. I am not quite sure what is on the minister's agenda, but I would hope that she would come clean because there is a great deal of unrest in the Lake Eyre basin catchment area as to what her agenda is following the South Australian conservation association move to list the Lake Eyre basin for world heritage. I would like to know—as I am sure the people of that region would like to know—what the minister really has in mind. Perhaps at the moment she is a little too busy reshuffling her 3,000-odd staff in Canberra, as reported in the Canberra Times only last week, to think of those people in that remote part of Australia.

I do want to refer back to the Murray-Darling. Last year, Queensland consented to join the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement. Many of the problems affecting our land and water resource are interrelated and cannot be effectively solved individually. There is widespread concern at the spread of land degradation, deteriorating water quality, rising ground water salinity and loss of native flora and fauna. In 1987, it was estimated that the losses to agriculture alone amounted to something like $260 million—and of course that figure pales into insignificance today because we have not really solved the problem yet—and costs due to river salinity amounted to $35 million a year.

The recent outbreaks of algal blooms are further testimony of the need for a coordinated approach to water management. Strict limits on the amount of phosphorus contained in detergents should be agreed to by all states in order to combat outbreaks of blue-green algae. The Queensland water quality task force recently handed down a report recommending that an upper limit of five per cent phosphorus in detergents be mandatory within 18 to 24 months. Similar reports undertaken by a New South Wales task force identified that phosphorus from household detergents passing into river systems through sewage treatment plants was a major source of nutrients for the blue-green algae. Up to half the phosphorus leaving sewage treatment plants comes from washing powders. The Queensland government must now follow the New South Wales lead by approving a five per cent limit by weight for phosphorus in detergents and laundry powders as that task force has found it is a major contaminant in our inland river systems. We cannot afford to have the blue-green algae problem ignored by state governments. Water management is their responsibility.

The blue-green algae was rampant through America and Canada in the 1960s when it was rumoured that Lake Erie was dead. Through an amendment to the Canadian water act, the amount of phosphorus in laundry detergents was limited to two per cent by weight. Prior to this amendment, the amount of phosphorus in laundry detergents was as much as 50 per cent by weight. Twenty years later, the algal blooms of Lake Erie are now at manageable and acceptable levels.

The existence of blue-green algae is a clear warning that Australian river systems are in trouble. This is a concern for all Australians and it should be tackled by a national agreement. Agricultural sources and urban run-off are also factors attributable to the blue-green algae epidemic. The problem in Queensland is not as severe as in the south-east of the continent, particularly in New South Wales. In fact, the Queensland section of the basin is quite different from those of the more southern states. The Queensland section of the basin covers 15 per cent of the state. It has major urban centres in its area: Toowoomba, Warwick, Dalby and Goondiwindi—just to name a few.

Industries serviced in the basin in Queensland include wool, beef, cotton, grain, horticultural and food processing. The Queensland rivers are rainfall run-off carriers and have no permanent flow base, unlike what we find in the Murray and Murrumbidgee where a lot of the run-off is sourced in the Kosciusko National Park and comes originally from the snowfalls. The Queensland rivers do not drain substantial ground water aquifers and, thankfully, have no salinity problems of any magnitude, unlike the situation in southern states. In the Queensland flood plain areas, the rivers simply represent a low flow channel which carries a small percentage of flood flows. On average, it is estimated that Queensland contributes only four per cent of the flow of the Murray River. Almost 90 per cent of the flow out of Queensland is lost on the flood plain and does not reach the Menindee Lake where the Murray-Darling regulations begin.

It is well recognised that the pastoral lands of western Queensland and New South Wales rely heavily on these flood flows to regenerate native pastures and timber in that area. The flows are therefore not entirely lost. Queensland is subject to an entirely different set of environmental conditions. The primary source of surface water for the basin is rainfall run-off occurring predominantly in the form of summer storms and the monsoonal wet season. The annual rainfall is highly variable and of course can vary from light falls to heavy tropical downpours. The tropical downpours are characteristic of Queensland weather patterns, while rainfalls in the southern states are much more moderate and Mediterranean in nature.

The fact that a lot of water originates from melting snow in the southern section of the Murray-Darling Basin further highlights the differences between Queensland weather patterns and those of the southern states. Such weather patterns result in different problems and therefore the need for different solutions. Queensland weather patterns call for greater storage needs, thus the prevalence of dams across the Darling Downs. Sections of the Queensland basin have evolved from treeless plains while certain sections of the New South Wales basin have evolved from eucalypt forests. So, while salinity may be a greater problem in New South Wales, Queensland has its share of erosion and soil management crises. Of course, a lot of it is caused by heavy rainfall patterns.

These differing concerns must not be overlooked with Queensland joining the Murray-Darling Basin Agreement.Queensland has also expressed concern that decisions made by the council, prior to Queensland joining, will have been made without full discussion from that perspective. Any decisions, therefore, should be clearly stated in the schedule to the agreement. Further conditions to agreements have included the retention of the Queensland border rivers agreement. This agreement has been in place between Queensland and New South Wales since 1946 and provides the water sharing negotiations across the border for the streams of the Murray-Darling Basin. Quite obviously, actions in Queensland do affect other parts of the basin. Although the Queensland section of the basin may not impact heavily on the rest of the basin, it is believed that the state borders should not be a major impediment to the cooperative nature of the resource management.

If, as a result of Queensland joining the agreement, a greater level of cooperation and understanding between all regions can be accomplished, the initiative will have been most worthwhile. Whilst this advantage is generally recognised by all communities of interest, concerns have been raised regarding the need to acknowledge the inherent difference between the Queensland region and the more southern regions of the basin. These concerns and differences must not be lost to a national agreement.

In conclusion, water management is of increasing and vital importance to the entire nation. National strategies must be adhered to while regional considerations must not be overlooked. We need a national agreement on the level of phosphates permeating our water systems, and we also need a more individual approach to the problems of salinity in New South Wales and erosion in Queensland. Resource and environmental degradation of the Murray-Darling Basin should be of concern to all Australians. The basin is Australia's most important agricultural resource. If water is the food of all life, the Murray-Darling basin is the lifeblood of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate you, Mr Deputy Speaker, on your appointment. I think this is the first time I have spoken with you in the chair. One may wonder why a person from a city electorate such as Dunkley, which takes in great areas such as Frankston and Chelsea, would speak on the Murray-Darling Basin. It has a great effect on us, especially on those of us who are environmentally aware and concerned. We do not have any large rivers on the Mornington Peninsula except one—which is called the Mornington Peninsula river. It flows from the Carrum sewage treatment plant down to Cape Schanck. Millions of litres of water are wasted every day from Melbourne's sewerage system; it just flows out into Bass Strait. That is a huge river of water just going to waste. This is something which has not been tapped. I am quite certain the lessons that the Murray-Darling Basin Commission learns will some day be able to be put to good use for all this water which is going to waste at the moment down at Cape Schanck. I can assure honourable members that even though the Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works says that it is treated effectively, it is not. My sons and daughter go surfing down that way, and they can tell many stories about what are commonly called `floaters' in the water. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) in his second reading speech said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Murray-Darling Basin comprises about one-seventh of Australia. It also produces about one-half of Australia's total output from natural resource based industries. It supports 25 per cent of the nation's cattle and dairy farms, about 50 per cent of its sheep, lambs and crop land, and almost 75 per cent of its irrigated land. Production derived is valued at some $10 billion annually. It is Australia's agricultural heartland.

The Murray-Darling is not only Australia's agricultural heartland; it is also regarded, regrettably, as Australia's biggest sewage treatment plant. The Murray-Darling Basin supports about 60 million sheep and about six million cattle. On top of these free range animals, there are over 250 cattle feedlots with approximately 300,000 head of cattle and also about 1.1 million pigs. They produce as much nitrogen as four million people and as much phosphorus as five million people. This is roughly as much as is contained in the sewage of Melbourne and Sydney combined. There are over 200 towns with a total population, I thought, of one million people, but the previous speaker, the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), said two million. I do not know how many there are, but there is an awful lot of people in there. Most of this sewage waste also goes into the Murray-Darling system.

PARA.TAB: Is it any wonder that the Darling River holds the world record for the largest toxic algal bloom recorded—1,000 kilometres of the Barwon and Darling rivers? Honourable members have all seen photographs of it on the TV. It shocked the whole of Australia, and it particularly shocked people living in that area. It had been predicted but, like most warnings given by scientists, the warning was ignored. However, in 1991 the combination of drought, high summer temperatures, low river flows—also depleted by pumping for irrigation—and, of course, nutrients from agriculture and townships created ideal conditions for this outbreak. People who normally took drinking water from the river had to stop and rely on rainwater tanks. The army was called in to supply water to the area. South Australia was particularly worried because 90 per cent of that state's population relies on this water—the same sewage contaminated water. Some of the toxins in it are deadly. A laboratory mouse injected with a solution of peptide heptatoxin will be dead between 30 minutes to 24 hours later. One solution to this problem would be to make certain that some sort of program was set in place to stop this effluent from getting into the rivers.

A division of forestry research team headed by Mr Brian Myers examined the use of treated sewage effluent for irrigating trees. Outside Wagga Wagga, in New South Wales, they are supplying a 7.5-hectare pine and eucalyptus plantation with water and organic wastes from sewage treatment works. Every day 4,500 billion litres of sewage effluent are pumped into Australia's rivers and oceans. This is a major source of nitrogen and phosphorus, and could be used to grow trees. Dr Myers estimates that effluent resource, as he calls it, in the Murray-Darling Basin is sufficient to support 18,000 hectares of tree plantations which are capable of supplying 360,000 tonnes of wood per year from land that would otherwise produce little useable timber. This is the sort of thing that could be done with the actual waste, which at the moment is flowing into our rivers in the Murray-Darling Basin—and some people in South Australia are drinking it. I am glad that I do not live there.

SPEECH.PARA: The direct costs of the Darling River bloom in 1991 were estimated to be at least $1.3 million. In South Australia the blooms during 1991-92 incurred a direct cost of around $400,000, and in Queensland about $200,000. This does not take into account recreation and tourism, which is also adversely affected. Losses of income for local shops and hotels were also not taken into account.

Water is a renewable resource. However, our land based water is dying because of how we treat it. We have dammed it, we have drained it, we have given it exotic plants and animals, and we have polluted it with everything imaginable. We can still repair our waterways and bring them back to life. This invaluable resource of water must be protected. People who use water must be educated in its use. They must pay the true price for water, especially irrigators. This will certainly make them use water wisely—and certainly upset them.

Some time ago the Central Darling shire persuaded the Department of Water Resources to release a small head of water from upstream irrigation dams above Bourke to flush the Darling from Bourke to Menindee. The head reached Tilpa—a hundred kilometres up river from Wilcannia. However, cotton farmers around Bourke were given permission to start pumping. They created such a hole in the river that the Darling actually flowed backwards, and the flush never even reached Wilcannia. This, of course, created some concern amongst those who had pushed hard for the flushing.

PARA.TAB: Water, as a resource, is becoming more and more valuable. Wars have been fought over it in the past. I have no doubt that as the last major war, Iraq versus the USA, was fought over a resource—oil—water could be a major trigger in any future conflict. Water creates other minor conflicts between neighbours. Water running off one property onto another property can create real problems. I notice that the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) is in the House. This matter relates to the area around Shepparton; he may even be aware of the case.

In the Shepparton area two farmers went to court to decide whether a levee bank built on one property could be allowed to stay because it stopped the natural flow of a watercourse. At one stage, both farmers had levee banks and water was being pumped onto the roadway between the properties. A very expensive and bitter court case followed which set a precedent regarding banks and drainage by ruling that the banks had to be pulled down. However, I believe the Victorian government has not yet acted to make certain that all these levee banks come down and many still remain. There is still much concern and conflict in the irrigation areas around Shepparton.

We in the city can play our part in conserving water. Many pamphlets are available with good ideas which can be put into practice by everyone. I do this myself in my own home. I have a rainwater tank, even though I live in the city. I have a device on the tank which, by pulling a lever, lets the rain flush my roof for about 10 minutes and then I fill up my tank. It is only a small 80-gallon tank, but the water certainly tastes a lot better than the water provided by the Board of Works in Melbourne these days. It is a lot cheaper, too.

In the time I have left I would like to raise an old idea but one which I think, with new technology and a better understanding of the interaction of water and our environment, may have some merit. It would certainly create a lot of jobs. I am talking about the Bradfield scheme. From time immemorial, people have dreamed of turning deserts into gardens. In Australia, the driest of the continents with its vast inland and arid areas, the thoughts of many people over the years have turned to diverting the northern coastal rivers of Queensland to irrigate large tracts of country in western Queensland and particularly the Lake Eyre basin.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development (Mr Lindsay), who is at the table, was instrumental in getting the Burdekin Dam built. It was the largest water resource project since I think the Ord River was built. It was an environmentally friendly dam and studies by AIMS made certain of this. I must say that construction of the Burdekin Dam was promised by all governments, but only one government delivered it: the Labor government. A lot of thanks must go to the parliamentary secretary for that.

Probably one of the greatest engineering challenges since European settlement of Australia would be to provide water for human enterprise in the vast inland areas of our continent. In the past, ideas such as the Bradfield scheme have been dismissed as being unworkable. But it has been proved that things which were considered impossible and impractical yesterday, are not so today through modern science and technology.

When this matter was first brought to my attention it fascinated me greatly, particularly when I found out that it was first discussed in 1887 by E.A. Leonard of the Queensland branch of the Royal Geographical Society. I then started to investigate. I unearthed a vast amount of information—much of it highly technical. Some of the main points are that the arid interior of Australia and the vast river system that drains towards Lake Eyre have always proved a challenge to the many dreamers over the years who wanted to make these dry lands bloom.

Their ideas have fallen largely into two categories. The first was the filling of the dry bed of Lake Eyre in the hope that evaporation from the water surface would cool and increase rainfall in the area. According to scientists, this idea would not work. One has only to look at the Dead Sea and other large inland areas where evaporation should take place—meaning therefore that this system should work—but has not.

The second idea involved the diversion of Queensland coastal rivers to feed the water courses of the inland system. Probably the most famous to promote such a scheme was, as I said, Dr Bradfield who made the first concrete proposal in 1938. Bradfield was a noted engineer who should also be remembered as a co-designer of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Turning deserts into gardens was a passion he held until his death in the early 1940s. He was quoted as saying:
Given water, central and western Queensland and the Lake Eyre basin could be made a veritable garden capable of producing everything required for the sustenance of man.

SPEECH.PARA: However, Bradfield was not the only one to advocate such a scheme. About the same time, in the late 1930s, author and traveller, Ion Idriess, also advocated a scheme for the irrigation of vast areas of central Australia. Broadly speaking, the object of the Bradfield and Idriess plans was to divert water from the rivers of Queensland for the irrigation of vast tracts in the Lake Eyre basin.

PARA.TAB: The gulf group of rivers comprises the Nicholson, Gregory, Leichhardt, Flinders, Norman, Gilbert-Staaten and Mitchell rivers, with a catchment area of around about 245,000 square kilometres and a probable yield of water of 6,793,000 megalitres a year. The east coast rivers drain a slightly larger catchment area of 285,000 square kilometres, which has a yield of about 130,000,000 megalitres of water. These are the Barron, Mulgrave, Russell, Johnstone, Tully, Herbert, Burdekin, Fitzroy and Burnett rivers. Some of those are counted out now and, because of the great work of the parliamentary secretary, one of them is already dammed.

The rivers of the Lake Eyre system do not have that much water running into them. They have a catchment area of around 273,000 square kilometres and a probable yield of around 2,890,000 megalitres of water. They drain the greater part of Queensland's interior and are marked by a gradual fall in elevation towards Lake Eyre.

In 1947, Andrew Lewis proposed that water be brought from the Snowy Mountains by way of the Murrumbidgee and Murray rivers and conveyed to Lake Eyre by means of an extension of the Morgan-Whyalla pipeline. However, the Snowy Mountains hydro-electric scheme, inaugurated in 1948, killed that idea. The Snowy Mountains scheme is the only large scale water diversion scheme so far successfully implemented in Australia. We can do more. There is water there; we just have to learn how to implement the schemes properly.

I can see nothing wrong with looking at this whole question again, even though it might be a bit strange. Some of the proposals that have been mooted around the place cannot, under any engineering proposal, work. However, with our new technology we may be able to achieve something—imagine the employment that such a project would create, to say nothing of the desolate land that could be rejuvenated and what could be produced.

Australia is on the threshold of a new exciting age. We are about to become a republic; to stand on our own. We are going to have closer ties with our Asian neighbours and we will have an increasing need for flexibility in order to meet changing market requirements. We are the world's best producer of quality food. Our production could increase dramatically with the opening up of new irrigation areas.

However, the challenge of this country, with its vast arid areas, remains as it did more than 50 years ago. But I feel that we are now better equipped to deal with it than ever before. Sooner or later we must meet this problem and solve it, as I fear the future development of Australia depends on the solution.

Even though we are moving more and more into the area of manufactured goods and are finding niche markets in this area we are still the world's best producer of food. We have the cleanest food. We do not have the problems experienced in Europe with radioactive pollution and so on which is spreading over the land. We do not have the chemical problems that some countries are trying so desperately to tell the rest of the world they do not have in order to sell their food. We do not have food that has been spoilt by unhealthy handling practices.

We should use this land in some way and it should be used for the betterment of not only those who live here but also the whole world. The way we can do that is by supplying the world with food. We are, as I have said, the best producer of food in the world. The Murray-Darling basin produces a huge amount of food and all of this should be put towards alleviating food problems elsewhere. Today we heard the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney) speak about Australia's overseas aid and how we give our goods, many of which are produced in the Murray-Darling Basin, to overseas countries. These goods, especially food, are our aid to disadvantaged people throughout the world.

The last minute before the budget is presented could be a very historic moment. So far as this parliament is concerned, from now on things will change in the rest of Australia. Members of the Liberal and National parties—I always like to have a go at them; I cannot stand here and not have a go—lost the last election because they were out of touch. They have never been in touch with the people. They agree with this legislation, which is good. Perhaps it will make them think a little more about the government's program and agree with it instead of continually knocking everything that the government does, which is what they do continually.

SPEECH.PARA: The greatest issue facing our nation is how to provide jobs for our fellow Australians. Too many are now out of work. Too many have been out of work for too long.

PARA.TAB: The primary objective of this budget is jobs: jobs in the short term by providing a further fiscal stimulus to the economy this year—to sustain Australia's economic growth until the motor of world recovery kicks in. And jobs in the medium and longer term by boosting the capacity of Australian businesses to expand production on a world-competitive basis. This is a budget to strengthen the recovery and make it sustainable.

Australia has had a number of economic recoveries in the post-war period, only to see them taper off prematurely. But this recovery is different. It is different, because firmly embedded into Australia's economic structure we now have two vital ingredients: inflation at levels lower than seen for 30 years; interest rates at their lowest in 20 years. These have been the twin goals of every government for a quarter of a century. But it is this government which has attained them, and harnessed them for the future benefit of all Australians. And that makes this recovery different. This is a quality recovery—a durable recovery.

Mr Speaker, this budget establishes an economic framework over four years: a framework for continuing low interest rates and continuing low inflation, which, combined with reduced company tax and generous investment incentives, will support increased business investment for future growth in production and employment. This budget sets us on a prudent path, leading to lower government deficits and higher national saving. This budget proposes measures which, overall, will cut the deficit four years from now by $9 billion. These steps will see the public sector directly contribute some $17 billion to the improvement of national saving over the three years to 1996-97.

The budget also takes action on government programs put forward in the context of the last election. Well over 100 separate spending commitments will be implemented. These will be fully funded over the course of the next four years. These commitments give effect to the government's plans to provide extra help to families with children, extra assistance to those out of work, improved health services, and other initiatives to make this society even fairer, even more cohesive. Other commitments include action to enrich the culture of our country, protect its environment, and support those living outside the major cities.

This budget will also provide new support for our emerging exporters, who are demonstrating such remarkable success in capturing new markets for products made and developed by the skilled hands and creative minds of Australia's working men and women.

The budget also provides relief for middle Australia by lowering marginal tax rates for those on incomes between $20,700 and $50,000. This will reduce the tax paid by a person on $600 per week by $8 per week. Not only will this promised tax cut be delivered, it will be delivered eight months early, commencing on 1 November 1993: just eleven weeks away.

This early payment is largely made possible by higher dividends from businesses like Telecom, and from the Reserve Bank. It is only right that taxpayers should benefit from the higher earnings of these publicly-owned bodies.

The government has decided to go further with the tax cuts by extending the benefits to low-income taxpayers. Those on incomes below $23,200 will receive a new rebate paid on assessment. This will relieve about 90,000 taxpayers of their entire tax bill, and ensure that a tax cut of $100 or more is paid to all other taxpayers annually.

The combined effects of the budget measures will result in a deficit of $16 billion this year. This will provide an extra stimulus of around $2 billion to Australia's economy at a time when a stimulus is needed to sustain the recovery.

SPEECH.PARA: THE ECONOMIC CONTEXT

PARA.TAB: Australia's subdued recovery in part reflects the time taken to recover from the sapping effects of the debt build-up and falling asset prices of the late 1980s. Of more importance, though, is the continuing weakness of the world economy. Whereas a year ago growth in the industrialised economies was expected to be three per cent in 1993, it is now expected to be a little over one per cent. Japan and Germany, the world's second and third largest economies, have yet to emerge from recession.

Against that background, Australia has done well and will continue to do so. Our GDP growth in 1992-93 was 2 1/2 per cent—a rate the envy of the industrialised world. Our relatively good performance can be attributed to two factors. First, the Government's foresight in building up budget surpluses in the late 1980s, and then using that capacity to provide a major fiscal stimulus to the economy when it was required. And second, our growing trade and investment links with the fastest growing region of the world—the dynamic economies of Asia.
Mr Speaker, the short-term outlook for the world economy remains subdued and therefore places a constraint on our own growth. The world outlook, however, is expected to improve during 1994.

Australia's challenge is to position itself to take full advantage of stronger world growth as it comes on stream and to continue our integration with the Asian economies. Above all, this will require the further development of world-class industries able to seek out and exploit new opportunities. That assures the best long-term prospect of reducing unemployment and raising Australian living standards.

Policy will have its part to play: by building on the substantial structural reform achieved over the past 10 years; by maintaining the much improved competitive position of our export industries—especially through low inflation; and by adjusting fiscal policy so that sufficient domestic saving is available to fund the additional investment required.

SPEECH.PARA: BUDGET STRATEGY

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, at the July Premiers Conference, all Australian governments agreed on the key challenge for fiscal policy today. The conference benefited from a major report on national saving commissioned from Dr Vince FitzGerald, a response to which I am releasing tonight.

The fiscal challenge is to continue the stimulus of activity over the next year to encourage economic recovery and job growth, while setting in train medium-term adjustments to significantly increase public sector spending. From next financial year, the process of withdrawing the stimulus and cutting the deficit will begin. Whilst the growth path of the economy will assist, on its own it will be insufficient to accomplish the task. This budget therefore contains measures which will accelerate the process.

Four years from now, the deficit will be cut to less than $6 billion, or around one per cent of GDP. This meets a key election commitment of the government. It will be achieved through five complementary steps.

First, the second round of tax cuts will be deferred from 1996 until a time when fiscal conditions permit, probably in 1998. Second, outlays will be reduced by $2 billion. Third, the income tax system will be tightened to remove or reduce certain concessions, and to tax non-cash benefits in a manner more equivalent to the taxation of the ordinary income of wage and salary earners. This will raise $600 million. Fourth, rates of excise on petroleum products and tobacco will be progressively increased. Fifth, wholesale sales tax rates will be increased in two stages over the next two years.

The effect of these outlays and revenue measures will reduce the prospective deficit for 1996-97 by $9 billion. But these changes will do more than that. They will halt the erosion of Commonwealth indirect tax revenues—thus preventing Australia's tax system becoming lopsided.

The share of tax revenue, other than from income tax, has fallen by almost a third—from 8.3 per cent of GDP in the mid-1980s to 5.9 per cent last year. Failure to act on the indirect tax side would create pressures for more weight on income tax, a weight which would fall more heavily on middle income earners.

The government will meet its announced objectives, without the introduction of a massive new indirect tax. The government will maintain indirect tax exemptions for the necessities of life. The government will maintain the system of higher tax rates for luxury items—such as fur coats, jewellery and expensive cars.

Compared with the taxation situation applying last financial year, the benefits flowing from the income tax cuts plus the new rebate amount to $1.7 billion this financial year, rising to $3.8 billion. The indirect tax increases raise $1.3 billion this financial year, rising to $3.0 billion.
In other words, in each year the benefits from the tax cuts will greatly exceed the extra indirect tax revenue—with these benefits being delivered to middle Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: MEASURES

PARA.TAB: I now move to the main aspects of the measures, full details of which are provided in supporting documents. Excise on petroleum products will rise by 3c a litre from tonight and a further 2c a litre a year later. An additional increase on leaded petrol will commence in February next year at 1c per litre rising to 5c per litre a year later. This recognises the harmful effect of lead in petrol, particularly on the children of Australia, and will accelerate the conversion of the motor vehicle fleet to unleaded petrol. Even if all these increases in fuel excises were implemented overnight, Australia would still have the third lowest petrol prices in the industrialised world—and amongst the lowest fuel taxes.

Excise on tobacco products will rise three per cent tonight and in four similar steps over two years. Excise on beer and spirits will remain unchanged. From tonight, the existing wholesale sales tax rates will increase by one per cent, and by a further one per cent in 1995. Wine is currently more lightly taxed than beer and spirits. From tonight, tax on wine will apply at the 31 per cent rate. But the government is committed to retaining the exclusion of wine from excise.

From tomorrow, lump sum payments of unused annual leave and long service leave will be taxed as normal income. But concessions will remain for those now aged 55 years or more, and those who leave their jobs through redundancy or for invalidity reasons. From April 1994, salary package benefits, such as membership of social clubs and similar items, will be fully subject to the fringe benefits tax arrangements, together with domestic travel expenses and accommodation costs in excess of reasonable levels.

Of the entire net revenue increase over the next four years from the budget tax measures: not $1 will go towards increased expenditure; not $1 will go towards meeting the government's spending commitments made at the time of the election. These spending commitments have been funded over the four years by reducing outlays in other areas.

I now turn to the key spending and savings measures. In the health area, savings will be achieved by reducing double dipping on Medicare benefits; reducing Medicare fraud and overservicing through new cooperative arrangements; and enhanced auditing of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The safety net for the PBS will be tightened for non-card holders.

Further savings will come from restricting access to Medicare benefits for optometry services. This will place optometry on a basis comparable to the new dental health program. The growth of defence spending will be reduced. The pension age for women will be increased to 65 in line with the pension age for men. But this will be gradually introduced over 20 years—minimising the impact on those approaching retirement.

The government is concerned that some families of fairly comfortable means have been able to exploit negative gearing to meet income test rules. From 1 January 1995, the income tests for a range of programs including Austudy and family payments will be changed, so that net losses from negative gearing of rental properties are added back to other income.

Secondary Austudy for students living at home will start in future at the age of 17. However, the additional family payment system will be extended. This will result in tighter targeting, and improved benefits to those families eligible for rent assistance.

New arrangements for the higher education contribution scheme will mean students commence repayments earlier and at higher rates, but with the income-contingent feature of the repayments preserved. The income test ceiling for the basic family payment will be lowered to $60,000, removing the benefit from the highest income six per cent of families currently receiving the payment.

Mr Speaker, this budget takes as a key objective the implementation of the government's election commitments. Over 100 of these commitments will have been met since the election and in this budget. Full details are set out in a special report included with the budget documents. The implementation of the remaining few is still being resolved.

I will deal with some of the major commitments briefly. The new Commonwealth dental health program will provide all health card holders with improved access to emergency care from next January—and basic dental care from six months later. The new child-care cash rebate of 30 per cent of claimable costs will be introduced from July next year, to be paid to eligible families regardless of income. A total of 230,000 Australian families will benefit from this measure, with payments of up to $28.20 per week for one child, and $61.20 for two or more children.

The new home child-care allowance will be paid from September next year. It will provide payments of up to $30 per week and will replace the dependent spouse rebate for couples with children. A total of 840,000 Australian families will benefit. This is a substantial and progressive change to Australia's income support system.

The new seniors health card will be provided, from 1 July next year, to low income retirees not currently receiving the pension. This will entitle some 200,000 older Australians to benefits which include concessional pharmaceuticals and hearing aids, and access to the new dental health program. The pension assets test will be eased with effect from September this year and will benefit around 60,000 non-pensioner and part-pensioner retirees.

Mr Speaker, this budget also contains a number of initiatives additional to those raised in the election context. The government said in the election that it would not forget the unemployed, nor leave them behind. To address this problem more fully, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has established a committee on employment opportunities, comprising recognised experts in this area. The committee is examining current policies on unemployment, and possible alternatives, and will prepare a discussion paper by December this year.

This will form the basis for broad community debate, leading to a government white paper on the issue. This will provide the forum for consideration of any new approaches for dealing with this very real social and economic problem.

But for now this budget will provide increased support for Australia's unemployed in two substantial ways. First, the total number of labour market program places available this financial year will be increased to over 500,000. Two-thirds of these are for people who have been unemployed for 12 months or more. Second, we will increase by $6 per fortnight the rate of newstart allowance paid to single adults without children, unemployed for more than 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: INVESTMENT AND TRADE

PARA.TAB: One sure way to reduce unemployment is through the expansion and development of Australian industry. That requires business investment and to secure that business investment, Australian governments need to create the most favourable environment for the expansion of productive business and jobs. Creating that environment requires the establishment of a stable framework for business planning. Crucial to that, there must be confidence that Australia's prospective budget deficit is being reduced substantially over the medium term.
At the same time, this Government is actively promoting Australia's economic transition through its taxation policy.

Action has already been taken to implement a number of election commitments in this area. Central to these was the reduction in the company tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent, effective from last July.
We have given investment an additional fillip by introducing a general investment allowance and have expanded the development allowance. This budget goes further by providing a boost to exporters.

Nowhere is Australia's economic transition more evident than in our trading performance. Exports account for 20 per cent of total goods and services we produce, compared with 13 per cent a decade ago. The composition of our trade has changed and matured. Exports of the more sophisticated manufactured goods have grown at 20 per cent annually over the last seven years. The destination of Australia's exports has also shifted dramatically, with Asia now taking almost 60 per cent of our merchandise exports. This partly reflects the much higher growth rates in Asia than in the older industrialised world. It also reflects our developing trade success in the region. We must build on the progress to date and encourage greater engagement with the Asia-Pacific region.

One initiative I am announcing tonight is the establishment of a committee jointly with the Northern Territory government to consider strategies to develop the potential of Darwin as Australia's northern link to east Asia.

McKinsey's recent study of emerging exporters revealed that much of the impetus for our recent export growth has come from 700 small to medium-sized manufacturing exporters. These exporters earned over $8 billion in 1990-91, double the level of four years earlier. According to that study, 90 per cent of Australia's manufacturers—more than 6,000 businesses—are not yet exporting, but most could, suggesting an undeveloped source of potential exports and employment.

The challenge is to see many more of these companies achieve their potential. Accordingly, $94 million will be provided over the next three years to fund a package of measures designed to encourage more small to medium-sized firms to commence exporting and to intensify the efforts of those existing exporters. These measures include the establishment of first stop shops, improvements to the export market development grants scheme, and the establishment of a `Market Australia' campaign.
Further details of the government's strategies to improve Australia's trade performance can be found in a separate paper, released tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: OTHER POLICY SETTINGS

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, other policy settings are also crucial to boosting Australia's competitive position. Wages policy is making its contribution, by supporting a more decentralised and flexible system to secure faster productivity growth.

Workplace bargaining is becoming the centrepiece of the system, with now over 1,000 federally registered enterprise agreements. Work practices can now be better attuned to the needs of individual firms.

Such changes could not have been achieved without the support and commitment of Australia's trade union movement. The government's accord with the ACTU will maintain the framework for reform, and increase the focus on workplace bargaining.
The government will protect vulnerable workers with legislation to guarantee minimum wages and conditions. We will also support an arbitrated safety net adjustment.

Mr Speaker, continued and accelerated structural reform is critical to increasing growth in the economy and expanding job opportunities. We have carried out extensive reforms in the past decade. Some of the payoffs are already evident and include lower domestic air fares, lower phone charges, greater labour productivity in shipping and on our railways, and better ship cargo handling rates and turnaround times. Such reforms improve Australia's prospects in an increasingly competitive world.
This process will be taken further when the government considers the report of the national competition policy review, which we expect to receive in the next few days.

SPEECH.PARA: ECONOMIC PROSPECTS/CONCLUSIONS

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, the budget I present tonight marks the commencement of a new era in Australian public finance. It is the first Commonwealth budget crafted within the framework of a national fiscal strategy—with its figuring informed by July's National Fiscal Outlook report.

It will be the last Commonwealth budget brought down in August. From next year, the budget will be delivered before the end of June. That will allow decision makers to plan for a full financial year, fully informed of the details of Commonwealth policy.

Tonight's budget is designed to fortify the framework of Australia's economic growth. In the short term, it provides a continuing stimulus while the economy is still being buffeted by weak international growth. Despite these headwinds, growth is expected to be a little stronger in the year ahead, and at a rate few other industrialised countries will exceed. Growth this year will be aided by continuing steady growth in private consumption, stronger public sector demand and a contribution from net exports.

Business investment is expected to improve. This augurs well for the future. It will help the recovery to gain momentum. Employment growth will begin to recover, but not fast enough to make major inroads into unemployment this year.

However, Mr Speaker, this budget is not just about this year. It is part of a longer term strategy: a strategy to build the savings of the nation as the economy recovers, so that private investment can be financed, and more of it financed at home; a strategy that builds on and complements the impressive progress already made in improving our economic strengths.

Over the next four years the economic transition we embarked upon 10 years ago will be taken further: the transition from being inward looking and highly protected to a modern world class economy; the transition from excessive reliance on our ties with Europe to participating in the opportunities provided by the economic dynamism of the Asia-Pacific region; no longer is Australia a European outpost on the far side of the world; we have seen the tyranny of distance give way to the blessing of proximity.

We have redirected our trade focus and diversified our export base. We are 30 per cent more competitive than we were 10 years ago. Productivity has grown by five per cent over the past two years. The profit share has recovered to the high levels of the late 1960s.

But beyond all else, the two most historically important achievements are those on inflation and interest rates. It is 30 years since inflation has been so low, and monetary policy will play its part in keeping core inflation low. It is 20 years since interest rates have been so low. These are achievements to be proud of. They are the vital building blocks for better investment and export performance. They result from a coordinated and coherent strategy of reform across all sectors of the economy. In the 1980s, Australia led the developed world in structural reform, and we are staying the course in the 1990s so as to maximise the benefits of the reforms to date.

Mr Speaker, this budget details a coherent and carefully designed plan for achieving the government's announced fiscal objective of reducing the deficit over four years. It continues the government's strong record of fiscal responsibility established in the 1980s whilst delivering on our election commitments and it does so by keeping Australia a low tax country and at the same time delivering substantial income tax cuts.

Next month, Australia will be confirmed by the OECD as the country with the lowest level of taxation in the industrialised world. The decisions announced tonight are designed to keep Australia in the low tax league.

Overall, tonight's budget reinforces the strengths on which Australia's long-term prosperity depends. It provides a prudent path to the future: a path leading to an Australia which saves more; a path leading to an Australia which can invest more in its own undoubted strengths; a path leading crucially to more jobs for our people. I commend the budget to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: This Loan Bill 1993 is a machinery financing measure to enable certain defence expenditures to be met from the loan fund rather than the consolidated revenue fund and to supplement the moneys available to the consolidated revenue fund.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this evening the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) announced as part of the 1993-94 budget a number of changes to the tax system. The Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993 will amend the tax laws to give effect to the most important of those changes. I propose to outline briefly the measures contained in this bill. PARA.TAB: The amendments contained in the bill will change the timing for the commencement of the two stage reduction in the tax rates announced in One Nation on 26 February 1992. The first stage will now commence on 1 November 1993, eight months earlier than scheduled. The bill provides that the second stage of tax cuts will commence at the beginning of a financial year to be fixed by regulation.

Because the first stage of the tax cuts will commence on 1 November 1993, the bill contains the new composite rate scales to apply for 1993-94 and the first stage rates for the 1994-95 and later income years. The new rates to apply from 1 November 1993 will benefit taxpayers with taxable incomes in excess of $20,700. The tax cuts will cost the revenue $1.66 billion this financial year. The ongoing cost to revenue of the first stage of the personal tax cuts is $2.9 billion in 1994-95 and $3.12 billion in 1995-96.

The bill will also provide a rebate of up to $100 to taxpayers whose taxable income for 1993-94 and subsequent income years is less than $23,200. The new rebate will mainly assist those taxpayers who do not benefit from the One Nation tax cuts.

Taxpayers with a taxable income of up to $20,700 will be entitled to a rebate of $100 in their assessments for the 1993-94 and later income years. The rebate will reduce at the rate of 4c in each dollar of taxable income in excess of $20,700 and completely phase out when taxable income reaches $23,200. The estimated revenue costs for this measure are $340 million in 1994-95, $330 million in 1995-96 and $320 million in 1996-97.

This bill will amend the Medicate Levy Act 1986 to increase the low income thresholds below which people will not be required to pay any levy. For 1993-94, individuals with taxable incomes of up to $12,688 and couples and sole parents with family incomes of up to $21,366 will not be required to pay the levy. There will be no change to the provisions which increase the threshold for couples and sole parents by $2,100 for each dependent child or student. The estimated cost of the increased low income thresholds is $30 million in 1993-94, $60 million in 1994-95 and $45 million in 1995-96 and 1996-97.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Unused annual leave and unused long service leave payments

PARA.TAB: The bill will remove the concessional tax treatment that applies to lump sum payments of unused annual leave and unused long service leave made on termination of employment so that, with two exceptions, such amounts are included in full in a taxpayer's assessable income.

One exception applies to taxpayers aged 55 or more on 17 August 1993. They will retain the current concessional treatment that applies to that portion of unused long service leave which accrued before 16 August 1978. The second exception applies to taxpayers whose termination of employment is as a consequence of bona fide redundancy or invalidity or is under an approved early retirement scheme. They will retain the existing tax treatment for both unused annual leave and unused long service leave.

The proposed amendments will ensure that the tax system does not discourage taxpayers from using their leave entitlements for their intended purpose. The amendments will apply to payments in respect of unused annual leave and unused long service leave made on or after 18 August 1993. The estimated gain to the revenue is $150 million in 1993-94, $325 million in 1994-95, $280 million in 1995-96 and $290 million in 1996-97.

The bill will remove the exemption from income tax for income in the nature of interest received by credit unions on loans made to their members and will allow credit unions to be taxed as cooperatives where they satisfy the requirements for that treatment. To give credit unions time to adjust to the new measures, there will be a phasing-in period.

The measure will remove the competitive advantage credit unions enjoy as a result of the special tax treatment given to them, and is consistent with the government's general approach of ensuring tax neutrality between business enterprises. The estimated gain to revenue is $25 million in 1995-96 and $30 million in 1996-97.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Taxation of friendly societies and other registered organisations

PARA.TAB: The bill will change the taxation treatment of friendly societies and other registered organisations. It will phase out, over three years from the 1994-95 year, the concessional tax rate for friendly societies in respect of their life insurance and certain other insurance business. As a consequence of that change, the bill will, from 1 July 1994 extend to friendly societies the same entitlement to deductions as is allowed to life insurance companies for the costs of getting in their life insurance premiums.

Another change will increase, from 1 July 1995, the rebate available to holders of friendly society life policies who are assessed on bonuses. This increase is a consequence of the phasing-out of the concessional tax rate. The estimated gain to revenue from these measures is $25 million in 1995-96 and $69 million in 1996-97.

The bill will also amend the income tax law so that, from 1 July 1994, a tax deduction for the cost of car parking for persons other than employees will be denied in certain circumstances. This will place car parking by self-employed persons on a comparable tax basis to car parking for employees.

A deduction for car parking expenses incurred by self-employed persons will only be denied where certain conditions apply. The rules for determining the non-deductible amount of a car parking expense in this bill are similar to the rules applicable to employers in valuing a car parking fringe benefit. The estimated gain to revenue of this measure is $70 million in 1995-96 and $35 million in 1996-97.

The income tax law will also be amended to allow deductions to employers for expenses incurred in providing their employees with a range of benefits, such as entertainment, club fees, leisure facilities, travel expenses of accompanying relatives, higher education contribution scheme payments and student financial supplement scheme payments. These expenses have previously not been deductible. Benefits of this nature, if provided to employees, are fringe benefits under the fringe benefits tax law. However, the taxable value of these benefits is reduced to the extent to which they are non-deductible to employers under the income tax law.

This amendment, which will apply from 1 April 1994, will allow a deduction to employers for these expenses under the income tax law. In consequence, it will subject these benefits to a fringe benefits tax liability. The estimated gain to revenue is $435 million in 1994-95, $240 million in 1995-96 and $240 million in 1996-97.

This bill will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Act 1986 to increase the current rate of fringe benefits tax from 48.25 per cent to 48.4 per cent. The increase will take effect from 1 April 1994 and will maintain the alignment of the FBT rate with the top marginal personal tax rate and Medicare levy rate. The increase reflects the increase in the Medicate levy rate, from 1.25 per cent to 1.4 per cent, on 1 July 1993. The estimated gain to revenue is $9 million in 1994-95 and $8 million in 1995-96 and 1996-97.

This bill will amend the fringe benefits tax law to impose fringe benefits tax on the amount of a travelling allowance received by an employee for travel in Australia which is in excess of a prescribed amount. The amount will be prescribed by regulation. The income tax law will also be amended to disallow expenditure incurred by employees or self-employed persons on travel expenses—such as accommodation, food, drink, and expenditure incidental to travel undertaken in Australia—which are in excess of the prescribed amount. The estimated gain to revenue is $60 million in 1994-95 and $45 million in 1995-96 and 1996-97.

I now turn to the three sales tax changes proposed in the bill. The first change will increase all sales tax rates by one percentage point, with effect from midnight tonight. This is expected to raise $435 million this year and $585 million in 1994-95. A further one percentage point increase for all sales tax rates will come into effect on 1 July 1995.

The second change will increase the rates of sales tax on wine, also with effect from midnight tonight. Compared to beer and spirits, wine is lightly taxed. While it is presently subject to sales tax, it does not carry any excise.

It is proposed to increase the rate of tax on wine with an alcoholic content of greater than 1.15 per cent from 20 per cent to 31 per cent. The rate of tax on low-alcohol wine, that is wine with an alcoholic content of 1.15 per cent or less, is to increase from 10 per cent to 21 per cent. Some low-alcohol wine is currently taxable at 20 per cent and its rate of tax will increase to 21 per cent in line with the proposed increase for all sales tax rates. The gain to revenue from this measure is estimated to be $70 million in 1993-94, $95 million in 1994-95, $105 million in 1995-96 and $110 million in 1996-97.

The last sales tax change will vary the rate of tax applicable to luxury motor vehicles, also with effect from midnight tonight. Luxury vehicles are currently taxable at 30 per cent on their entire wholesale value. The current sales tax treatment results in a substantial pricing distortion: the addition of $1 to the wholesale price of a passenger motor vehicle now priced at the threshold would increase the sales tax liability by $4,873.

It is proposed to remove this distortion by applying a split rate of sales tax to luxury motor vehicles. Broadly, the ordinary rates of sales tax applicable to motor vehicles will apply up to the wholesale luxury threshold. A rate of 45 per cent will apply to that portion of the wholesale value over the luxury threshold. The gain to revenue from this measure is estimated to be $5 million in 1993-94 and $10 million in 1994-95, 1995-96 and 1996-97.
Full details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum being circulated to honourable members. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Has Telecom investigated providing local telephone calls free of charge; if so, what were the conclusions; if not, will he instigate an investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on advice from Telecom, is as follows:

PARA.TAB: As a Government business enterprise, Telecom is responsible for making its own commercial and management decisions within the context of legislative requirements and Government policies. In particular, Telecom has responsibility for setting charges for services. While Part 6 of the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Act 1991 provides that the Minister may determine general price control arrangements for Telecom, subsection 9(2) of the Act provides that the Minister "must not give a direction . . . in relation to the amounts to be charged for work done, or services, goods or information supplied, by AOTC."

Telecom has advised that it has investigated the practice of certain overseas countries of providing "free" local calls. This normally involves the payment of a monthly fee to cover an amount of network usage.
Telecom advises that it does not consider such a scheme to be a practical option, since it would disadvantage about 40 per cent of Telecom's customers who have a small daily calling rate.

Telecom further informs me that, if not recovered through a direct usage charge, the cost of providing local calls would need to be recovered through some other means. Typically, in those administrations where local calls are provided "free", the cost is recovered through higher access charges (that is, rental charges) or is subsidised by long distance charges.
As this is a matter for Telecom's commercial judgement, I do not propose to intervene.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)(a) The capital gains tax (CGT) provisions of the taxation law are intended to operate in a broad range of situations. They generally apply where an asset is acquired and disposed of after 19 September 1985, and where certain capital payments are received after that date. The Government is not aware of any circumstances where the CGT provisions operate in an unexpected manner.

(b) The CGT provisions do not usually apply on the death of a person—liability to tax is generally rolled-over to successors and is assessed on a subsequent disposal of the asset by the successor. There are two exceptions to this general rule. The first is where an asset passes to a beneficiary whose income is exempt from tax or is concessionally taxed. The second is where a non-taxable Australian asset passes to a non-resident beneficiary. In both of these situations, the deceased is taken to have disposed of the asset to the beneficiary immediately before his or her death. This ensures that any capital gain which accrued while the deceased owned the asset is appropriately taxed.

The taxing of the assets of a deceased in these situations is limited to any gain which accrued in respect of those assets that were acquired by the deceased after 19 September 1985. This does not mean that CGT operates as a form of death duty which, by contrast, is generally payable on the whole value (after allowance for certain exemptions and deductions) of the entire estate of the deceased.

PARA.TAB: (1) As the Honourable Member will appreciate from the answer which was provided to his identical question on notice on 4 November 1992, the issues raised by the High Court's decision in the Mabo case are complex. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 6 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Is he able to state at what rate unemployment benefit or its equivalent is paid in (a) Australia, (b) the UK, (c) Canada, (d) the Netherlands, (e) Germany and (f) Sweden.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: In Australia, unemployment payments are $141.35 a week for single people and $260.30 a week for a married couple. Additional payments are made for children.

The UK system of unemployment payments is two-tiered. A flat rate unemployment benefit payment, dependent on national insurance contributions, is payable for up to twelve months. The current single rate is 44.65 pounds a week (the equivalent of $99.20) and the rate for couples 72.20 pounds a week ($160.45). Additional payments are made for children.

The second tier is income support. For people who have no entitlement to unemployment benefit or whose income is below a minimum level, an income support payment may be available. The amount payable is individually assessed taking into account financial resources such as income and savings. As at 1 October 1992, the maximum single rate (25 years and over) of income support was 42.45 pounds a week ($94.30) and the rate for couples was 66.60 pounds a week ($148.00). Additional payments are made for children.

The Canadian System is also two tiered. 95 per cent of Canadian workers have unemployment insurance (UI). The UI rate is 60 per cent of the claimant's average weekly insurable earnings. The maximum amount a person can claim under UI is $CAN425 a week, or as at 28 May 1993, the equivalent of $490.20 weekly.
The second tier is provincial welfare support. The amount paid varies between Provinces. An uninsured person would usually rely on provincial welfare schemes for income support.
In the Netherlands, benefit is 70 per cent of the last earned wage. The minimum amount payable is 357.10 guilders a week; as at 28 May 1993, the equivalent of $299.80 weekly.
Germany provides an unemployment benefit from its contributory system equivalent to 68 per cent (for those who are married) or 63 per cent (for those who are single) of after-tax earnings.

The percentage calculation is based on earnings prior to unemployment. The calculation is subject to an earnings ceiling. In June 1992, the ceiling was DM1,590 a week or DM6,800 a month. As at 28 May 1993, the equivalent in Australian Dollars is respectively $1,421.20 weekly or $6,077.90 monthly. This means that maximum weekly benefits in the vicinity of DM1,081—as at 28 May 1993, $966.20—or monthly benefits up to DM4,624—as at 28 May 1993, the equivalent of $4,133.00—could be derived from the scheme.

Alternatively, Germany pays an unemployment assistance to workers ineligible for coverage from the general insurance scheme. This is means tested on a base of 58 per cent (for married people) or 56 per cent (for those who are single) of previous after tax earnings. Unemployment assistance is also available to workers insured under the general insurance schemes, whose entitlement to regular coverage expires (duration is dependent on the age and the period of insurance of the unemployed).

The Swedish system is also two tiered. Approximately two thirds of employees are covered by unemployment funds established by trade unions. They are paid a variable rate according to a wage and fund classification.

The rates are between 198 and 564 kronor a day or at 28 May 1993, the rates are between $39.50 and $112.50 daily. The actual rate is determined by applying 90 per cent of the insured person's previous daily earnings.
There is also a labour market support program which covers people not in the union funds. The rate of benefit paid under this program is 198 kronor a day—or as at 28 May 1993, $39.50 daily.
The Financial Review dated 28 May 1993 has provided the exchange retail rates.
