TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 6 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Are there problems associated with the transitional arrangements for some Australian Defence Force personnel to the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme; if so,
(a) did a Retirement Benefits Office document recently highlight them, (b) what are the problems, (c) what are the budgetary implications, and (d) will the Government correct the problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (a) Yes, but I would note that the problem had been recognised (see my answer to (b) below) and consideration of options for rectification had already been addressed at Ministerial level.

(b) On 9 September 1992, the Senate disallowed MSBS Instrument No. 2 of 1992. The main thrust of Instrument No. 2 of 1992 concerned members of the DFRDB Scheme who had broken periods of service and who were making additional contributions to the DFRDB scheme to purchase the earlier service. The issue that led to disallowance was the way in which those contributions were treated on voluntary transfer to the new military superannuation scheme, the MSBS.

As well as dealing with the purchase of service, Instrument No. 2 sought to correct a drafting error in the MSBS Rules which resulted in some pensioners who had re-entered the ADF receiving a double benefit.

There are two groups of members eligible to receive double benefits because of the drafting error: DFRDB members who had retired with a pension; and DFRDB members who had separated from the Defence Force and transferred their DFRDB benefits to another superannuation scheme, for instance, the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme. Where a member of either group reentered the Defence Force and then transferred to MSBS, the DFRDB benefit from the first period of service was retained by the member and an MSBS benefit would become payable for the second period of service.

In addition to these intended benefits, the drafting error resulted in an unintended benefit. The drafting error allows all contributions paid during the first period of service, together with notional interest on those contributions, to be paid to the member on retirement. This means that the member not only retains the benefit from the first period of service for which the contributions were paid, but also has the contributions and interest paid as an addition to the MSBS benefit.
The Acts Interpretation Act prevented another amendment to the Rules to achieve the same end being made before 9 March 1993.
(c) To date, 44 members have exited under the original rule with a total liability of some $4.8 million. None of the benefits have been paid pending a legislation solution to the problem.

(d) Yes. When the original instrument was disallowed by the Senate, no objection was raised to the removal of the double benefit except for the fact that the MSBS Board of Trustees had not been consulted. The Board has since agreed to steps being taken to remove the double benefit. A further instrument correcting the drafting error was signed by Minister Ray on 19 April 1993 and took effect on 22 April 1993.
Any affected member who exited before 27 May 1992 or who exited after 9 September 1992 and before 22 April will be legally entitled to the double benefit.

Because the Acts Interpretation Act prevents the amending Instrument operating retrospectively, at least $4.8 million will have to be paid to those ADF members who have retired unless the MSBS Act is also amended. The Government has agreed to a retrospective amendment to the MSBS Act to ensure that all affected members are excluded from the unintended double benefit.

As the Board of Trustees cannot legally withhold the double benefit in question from members who claim it, it is proposed to write to those members affected and explain the situation to them, clearly indicating that if they choose to access the double benefit on exit, it will be repayable to the Commonwealth after the passage of the amending legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 6 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What are the details of the type and extent of any damage to stockpiled wool resulting from the length of time of storage, band rust, compression altering the wool's characteristics and other causes.
(2) What steps (a) can be and (b) are being taken to lessen the damage.
(3) What are the costs involved in the damage and lessening it.
(4) Has the damage affected sales of the wool.
(5) What is the prospect of further damage occurring.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) There is no empirical evidence available to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission (AWRC) to suggest deterioration to wool's characteristics as a result of the length of time or form of storage.
Fabric moth has been found in a small number of storage sites. There is no evidence of damage occurring to the wool as a result of the presence of this insect.
Damage has, however, resulted from water infiltration into AWRC stores and leased premises. Approximately 37,000 bales have been affected.

(2) The AWRC maintains an active risk management program to ensure that all reasonable steps are taken to minimise the chances of losses occurring. AWRC staff regularly inspect storage sites to ensure that wool stocks are maintained in a pest free, safe and secure environment. The AWRC has determined that wool located in high risk stores will be relocated to high quality warehouse premises. This process will be completed in the near future.

(3) Two major losses have resulted from water damage. Re-handling charges and loss of wool in these instances amount to approximately $7.0 million. A large proportion of these losses is expected to be recovered from insurers.

Net additional storage costs as a result of the relocation of wool from high risk premises will amount to approximately $1.0 million per annum. The pest control program costs around $0.4 million per annum.
(4) The AWRC generally re-handles or processes damaged wool before it is offered for sale. Re-handled or processed wool is therefore classified as undamaged.

Wool has been offered for sale in a "damaged" condition in a few instances. On such occasions, potential buyers are made fully aware of the cause and extent of damage, and are offered the opportunity to inspect the wool prior to submitting bids. To date, no problems have been encountered as to the saleability of these limited quantities of damaged wools.

(5) All reasonable measures are being taken to ensure that the wool stockpile is maintained in good condition. Other than losses occurring from natural disasters, the AWRC does not foresee further losses occurring.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Taxation: Effect of Value of Shares

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 10 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: Is the amount of taxation payable affected by fluctuations in the value of shares; if so, what financial penalty would be applicable to a taxpayer receiving a gross salary of $167,000 who had bought shares at $5.00 in June 1990 and the market value fell to $3.00 on 23 September 1992 and then rose to $4.00 on 23 September 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: As the question relates to the market value of shares, it is assumed that it is directed at the new income tax measures which were implemented on 1 January 1993, namely, the Foreign Investment Fund (FIF) measures. The measures operate to accrue income to an Australian resident from the holding of a share in a foreign company or an interest in a foreign trust. These foreign companies and trusts are referred to as foreign investment funds (FIFs).

In view of the limited amount of information provided in the question, it is not possible to determine whether an amount of tax is payable because of a fluctuation in the price of the shares. The reason is that, in order to narrow the focus of the FIF measures to only target those investments that provide the greatest opportunity for deferral of Australian tax, there are a significant number of exemptions. Some of the major exemptions are for:
(a) individuals with FIF interests, including those of their associates, that do not exceed $50,000;
(b) direct investments in foreign companies which are principally engaged in active businesses;
(c) certain interests in foreign banks, insurance companies, real property companies and specified multi-industry companies;
(d) interests in FIFs that are trading stock;
(e) certain balanced investment portfolios;
(f) Australian residents who are taxed under the controlled foreign company and transferor trust measures.

If the Australian taxpayer is not covered by one of the FIF exemptions, there are three possible methods of calculating the amount of FIF income to be included in the taxpayer's assessable income. These are the market value method, the deemed rate of return method and the calculation method. Given that your question provides information relating to fluctuations in the market value of shares, I will assume that the market value method would be appropriate to the circumstances of the taxpayer.

As the FIF measures did not commence until 1 January 1993, the market value of the shares on 23 September 1992 is not relevant. However, I will assume that, at the relevant day (i.e., 31 December 1992) for the taxpayer's current income year (i.e., 1992/93 income year), the market value of the shares is $3.00. Given that the taxpayer's 1992/93 income year would normally end on 30 June 1993, the market value of the shares on 23 September 1993 would also not be relevant. However, I will assume that the market value on 30 June 1993 is $4.00.

On the basis of these assumptions, during the relevant period (i.e., from 1 January 1993 to 30 June 1993) the market value of the shares has increased by $1.00. Assuming that no transactions had taken place in relation to these shares during the relevant period, an amount (called FIF income) of $1.00 times the number of shares would be included in the taxpayer's assessable income for the 1992/93 income year and would be taxed at the taxpayer's marginal rate of tax.

In reply to this question, it is also assumed that, during the relevant period, the shares were not sold by the taxpayer. In the event that the shares were sold, the normal capital gains tax provisions of the income tax law would apply instead of the FIF measures.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 11 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which organisations were consulted in the drafting of the Radiocommunications Act 1992.
(2) Was the Wireless Institute of Australia consulted in the drafting of the legislation.
(3) What is the purpose of the legislation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beddall The Hon D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Prior to the drafting of the Radio-communications Act 1992, public seminars were held in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra to outline the scope of the reforms to the management of the radio-frequency spectrum and to obtain comments on the proposals. Discussions with other interested bodies were held in Brisbane and Adelaide. Over 150 invitations were issued to a wide cross-section of users, industry representatives, industry associations and government bodies. The Radiocommunications Consultative Council (RCC) was specifically consulted on the legislation. The members of the RCC includes representatives of industry, users, consumers and government authorities.
(2) The Wireless Institute of Australia attended the Melbourne public seminar mentioned above and had the opportunity to express any views at the seminar or in writing.
(3) The purpose of the Radiocommunications Act 1992 is set out in Section 3 of the Act as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: "3. The objective of this Act is to provide for management of the radiofrequency spectrum in order to:

PARA.TAB: (a) maximise, by ensuring the efficient allocation and use of the spectrum, the overall public benefit derived from using the radiofrequency spectrum;
(b) make adequate provision of the spectrum for use by public or community services;
(c) provide a responsive and flexible approach to meeting the needs of users of the spectrum;
(d) encourage the use of efficient radio-communication technologies so that a wide range of services of an adequate quality can be provided;
(e) provide an efficient, equitable and transparent system of charging for the use of spectrum, taking account of the value of both commercial and non-commercial use of spectrum;
(f) support the communications policy objectives of the Commonwealth Government;
(g) provide a regulatory environment that maximises opportunities for the Australian communications industry in domestic and international markets;
(h) promote Australia's interests concerning international agreements, treaties and conventions relating to radiocommunications or the radiofrequency spectrum."

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 11 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Were the skeletal remains of 297 Australian Aboriginals returned to Australia from Edinburgh University in 1991.
(2) Have any of the remains been returned for burial to the areas from which they came; if so, (a) how many and (b) where and when were they returned.
(3) Are any of the remains being held in Canberra; if so, (a) how many, (b) why are they being held and (c) how long will they be held.

(4) Is it a fact that (a) the return of the remains from Edinburgh University was sought with urgency and enthusiasm and (b) a significant number are still being held in Canberra; if so why was there any need for urgency.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The skeletal remains of 299 Aboriginal Australians were returned from the Edinburgh University in 1991.

(2)(a)&(b) 28 skeletal remains have been returned for reburial. In December 1991 23 skeletal remains were returned to the Aboriginal Cultural Heritage Advisory Committee of the Museum of Victoria for reburial. In February and April 1992, two, one and two skeletal remains respectively were returned to the Tweed Byron Aboriginal Land Council, the Moree Aboriginal Land Council and the Mungindi Aboriginal Land Council all in New South Wales.

(3)(a)(b)&(c) 271 skeletal remains from the Edinburgh University are being held in Canberra under the provisions of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984. Copies of documentation provided by the Edinburgh University were provided in l991 to the relevant State and Territory Governments, with the request that the skeletal remains be collected from Canberra and, following consultations with the communities of origin, returned to these communities. However the Edinburgh University was only able to provide poor and inadequate documentation on a considerable proportion of the collection. To address this particular issue, ATSIC is to commission a report which is to provide advice on how best to proceed with returning skeletal material where as yet it has not been possible to identify the exact areas or places of origin. This consultancy, and further consultations with Aboriginal communities as to their wishes for reburial, will be undertaken later this year.

(4) The return of the 299 skeletal remains from the Edinburgh University occurred because of a decision of that University to return the remains to Australia. Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people accepted that decision, notwithstanding the poor information held by the University as to the origin of much of the skeletal remains.
